Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VN8-FXT1-JBHT-D3N7-00000-00NYT: Facebook Data Deals Under Criminal Investigation; U.S. Grounds Boeing 737 Max; Actress Posts $1M Bond; USC To Boot Students; Huawei Heading To Court; Beto Announces 2020 Bid; Andrew Weissmann Will Soon Leave the Justice Department; Gambino Crime Boss Killed; Panther's Stadium Value; College Admission Scandal2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNYT: Facebook Data Deals Under Criminal Investigation; U.S. Grounds Boeing 737 Max; Actress Posts $1M Bond; USC To Boot Students; Huawei Heading To Court; Beto Announces 2020 Bid; Andrew Weissmann Will Soon Leave the Justice Department; Gambino Crime Boss Killed; Panther's Stadium Value; College Admission ScandalLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday, everybody, good morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 14th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. Facebook reportedly facing a criminal investigation now. At the central of the probe, the social media giant's data deals with other technology companies, it comes after a major outage at Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp last night.

Grounded now, President Trump is keeping all Boeing 737 Max jets in the U.S. parked as new reports say that the Ethiopian Airlines crash shows similarity to last year's Lion Air accident. There was evidence at the scene of that Ethiopian accident which caused the President to ground these planes.

A deadly and historic blizzard, bringing hurricane-force winds to the Central United States. More than 1,000 flights canceled at Denver's airport this morning. The storm is set to affect more than 70 million Americans. And out on bond, actress Lori Loughlin is posting $1 million in bond after appearing in court for her alleged role in the college admission scandal -- we have the very latest. There's a new report says that the scam was uncovered by accident. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: All right. Markets this morning are higher. Take a look, Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading this morning. The Dow Industrials right now up 50 points, as you see, a quarter of a percent. S&P 500 also higher by 4-1/2, and the NASDAQ up 17-1/4 points this morning. It looks like we will see a firmer opening this morning once the market is open.

Our top story this hour, Facebook is under fire again this morning. The company reportedly facing now a criminal investigation over controversial data-sharing deals. This, after a major outage hit Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp across the globe. Dagen McDowell, good morning to you. Dagen, what's your take?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That it's just incredible the way the story is developing and the recklessness that Facebook behaved with in terms of revealing people's data on the service. So, this is according to the New York times, that federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation into these data-sharing deals that Facebook struck with some of the world's largest technology companies. Again, shining an even brighter spotlight on the social media companies' business practices.

There's -- a grand jury in New York had subpoenaed records from at least two prominent makers of smart phones and other devices. This is according to reporting in the New York Times. These companies are among 150, including Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, and Sony, that at one point, cut data-sharing deals with Facebook. The agreement which were originally revealed in the New York Times let these companies see users' friends, contact information, other data about individuals, sometimes without consent.

Facebook says that it's phased out most of these partnerships over the last couple of years. This -- so this is a -- this is a grand jury of inquiry overseen by prosecutors. This is the eastern district of New York, but let's also talk about the federal trade commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission are looking into Facebook's behavior. Also, the Justice Department's securities fraud unit has been investigating. And this is in the northern district of California. The situation around the Cambridge Analytica data sharing. Remember Facebook back in -- I think it was 2011, signed a consent agreement with the Federal Trade Commission because it was sharing data in ways that deceit consumers, what's the fallout from that?

Meantime, Facebook was down yesterday, also Instagram, also WhatsApp, it owns all three of those companies. Down for at least 11 hours as of early Thursday, and the outage could force Facebook potentially to issue refunds to advertisers. And, of course, we were all just angry as you know what, that we couldn't get on to Instagram yesterday. Right, Maria? Back to you.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Yes, we were. But this criminal investigation is a big story. Wow.

MCDOWELL: Indeed. And again, where does it lead, and is Facebook now face -- remember, it's going to pivot its business to a more private communications. Well, nothing is -- nothing is private if you're operating on a Facebook platform. I think that the company has made that pretty clear.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because that's how they make money.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Advertising and data. All right, Dagen, we'll keep following that. Meanwhile, this is the big story as well, this morning, grounding the 737 Max altogether. The United States making this decision with the Federal Aviation Administration, after finding new data linking Sunday's Ethiopian Airlines crash and last October's Lion Air crash. President Trump commented on the move.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED: We're going to be issuing an emergency order of prohibition to ground all flights of the 737 Max 8 and the 738 Max 9, and the planes associated with that line. Planes that are in the air will be grounded if they are the 737 Max, will be grounded upon landing at the destination. The pilots have been notified. Airlines have been all notified. Airlines are agreeing with this, the safety of the American people and all people is our paramount concern.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Roman & Associates founder and CEO, Anthony Roman. Anthony, thanks very much for weighing in here.

ANTHONY ROMAN, FOUNDER & CEO, ROMAN & ASSOCIATES: Sure.

BARTIROMO: This is one of the most widely used planes across the country, right, and the world?

ROMAN: It is becoming one of the most widely used planes. And it's a fascinating aircraft with a 10 percent savings in fuel consumption. That's an enormous amount of money during global operations. It's also the best-selling aircraft in history, 5100 firm orders for Boeing. And Boeing is set to lose $25 billion in market value.

BARTIROMO: Right, it's already lost 25 billion market value since the Ethiopian crash happened. The stock is down about 10 percent. But what about this plane, what do we need to know about this plane? I mean, the fact that the FAA is now grounding all of the planes, travelers also are reacting to the 737's grounding. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I do trust airlines. I do understand that any aircraft or any kind of anything could have an issue at any time. It doesn't mean everything is bad, or -- I feel pretty safe flying.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Actually, I was flying back from Daytona Beach, American Airlines today. Did a couple of flights, and I wanted to make sure what plane I was getting on, because I've probably wouldn't have gotten on the Max.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There's a known safety concern, and certainly we're putting in the effort to figure it out before anything else happens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Anthony, what's your take on all of this?

ROMAN: Well, you know, pilots knew there was a problem, the FAA knew there was a problem, prior to Lion Air and immediately following Lion Air. The FAA reported in a worthiness directive, to of Boeing to redo some of the computer code on the MCAS and auto pilot system. That's not done unless they know there is some type of flaw in the system. But they have not reported to the public what that flaw may have been.

There were five pilot reports to the National Safety Reporting System. Identical problems to the Lion Air situation and similar to what we see on the satellite data in the oscillations in the takeoff phase, in Ethiopian air as well. And these captains, seasoned U.S. carrier captains reported to NASA that there were pitch oscillations, pitched down uncommanded actions by the aircraft, auto-throttles during the takeoff phase, not being in the correct position despite the input data placed in the computers by the pilot are verified to be correct. So, all sorts of problems with this aircraft.

The issue is, these airplanes are much more complicated than airplanes in the early 2000s, the 90s, and the 80s. These are highly-computerized machines, so not only are we dealing with more complexity in engines and systems, but now hundreds, if not millions of lines of code in these computer systems that have to be dealt with.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. Because after the Lion Air crash, the CEO of Boeing told us that there were -- there was an issue that needed -- the pilots needed to be updated about, that the plane was upgraded, there was a change in some of the operations, the pilot needed to be aware of those. Is there -- is it beyond that that the pilots just need to be educated about this plane, or is it something bigger than that?

ROMAN: Well, usually, accident phases are a combination of issues. And the pilot, the lack of pilot awareness that this system was operating in the background, and the lack of pilot training to overcome, to recognize and overcome any anomalies in this system is just a failure. Basically, it had to be a cost-savings failure, because training time costs money, and the aviation industry is constantly trying, like all businesses, to drive its cost down. Not the best way to do it.

BARTIROMO: No, we'll be watching this. Obviously, a major impact to Boeing, but the safety of Americans is the administrations show its concern so they grounded all of them. Anthony, thanks very much for weighing in. Appreciate it very much. Anthony Roman joining us there.

Meanwhile, as you saw on the screen, Beto O'Rourke officially announcing his 2020 Presidential bid. We're going to talk about that this morning. And then there's this, deadly blizzard conditions in Colorado and across the country this morning. Cheryl Casone with all of that in headlines. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria, good morning. Nearly 1400 flights canceled at Denver International after a bomb cyclone hit the airport there. Look at these pictures, wind gusts as strong as 80 miles an hour. Elsewhere in Colorado, a police officer hit and killed while outside his vehicle, helping with the car that had skidded off of Interstate 76. Now, to Texas, small planes overturned like toys at a municipal airport by high winds. Strong winds also a major problem in New Mexico that caused a train to derail there. This is incredible.

And then, look at this, again, back to Texas, stunning videos, strong winds blew over a tractor trailer. It was -- it was unbelievable. We'll show it to you, hopefully, in a moment. It wasn't the only one, though, there's been reports of wind speeds up to 70 miles per hour, causing multiple trucks to blow over. This is happening in different parts of the country. No word on the conditions of the driver. Again, we'll get that video to you later in the show.

All right, the college admission scandal is now in federal court, actress Lori Loughlin posting $1 million bond in Los Angeles. She and her fashion designer husband are among 50 people facing fraud charges for allegedly paying bribes to get their daughters into colleges. One of the schools in the heart of the scandal, University of Southern California. The university says applicants who are connected to the admissions cheating scheme are going to be denied admission. A case-by-case review will be conducted for students who are already enrolled at USC and may be connected to the scheme.

And ABC News reports the FBI uncovered the $25 million nationwide college admissions cheating scandal by accident, while agents were working on unrelated securities fraud cases. The agents reportedly received a tip from somebody that was connected to the investigation about the alleged bribe, paid to the then-head women's soccer coach at Yale. Maria, this story just continues to fascinate the country, and a lot of kids that didn't get into those schools, I'm sure, are pretty angry as their parents are as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. With good reason. Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: Uh-hmm. You bet.

BARTIROMO: Breaking news, as we just heard, Beto O'Rourke makes his Presidential announcement official. We've got a lot more on that after a short break. Stay with us, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big show this morning. Coming up right here, South Dakota Senator and Armed Services Committee member Mike Rounds is with us. Oregon Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member Greg Walden with some breaking news this morning from him. Former senior adviser to President George W. Bush, and Fox News Contributor Karl Rove joining us after an op-ed this morning. And former Presidential candidate and former Arkansas Governor, Mike Huckabee, joining us as well. Big three hours ahead. Don't miss a moment of it.

We want to talk right here about Huawei. It is in court today, lawyers for the Chinese telecom giant expected to appear in federal court later this morning, to answer charges that the company violated Iran trade tensions. Huawei is accused of dealing with Iran through a front company in Hong Kong. The company's Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou was arrested in Canada, accused of lying to banks about it. She's now awaiting extradition to the United States.

Joining the conversation this morning, Forbes Media Chairman and former Republican Presidential candidate Steve Forbes joining us here. Along with national security analyst and Fox News Contributor Morgan Ortagus. Great to see everybody this morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thanks. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: You're welcome. Yes, I mean, this Huawei story keeps getting worse. I know that they arrested her because of the Iran sanctions, and dealing with Iran. But there's also obviously, the privacy issues and the espionage that we've been talking about so much, Morgan.

ORTAGUS: Yes. And the Iran sanctions violations are very serious. I mean, what we've seen is over the past 10 years, probably, millions and millions of dollars paid by financial institutions, especially those based in New York as it relates to Iran sanctions. You're seeing most major banks on Wall Street have mediators and have people that are working on a daily basis to improve their systems, so they don't evade sanctions. So, to think that this is a sort of a one-off for this company is actually wrong. I mean, anybody in Wall Street can tell you that they're running scared of any sort of violation of Iran sanctions. It's quite serious.

BARTIROMO: I mean, I look at the Iran sanctions as one part of it, but really, the more -- the interesting part from my standpoint is the espionage issues, and the fact that it's gone across the world and to African countries and European countries, will set up your telecom infrastructure. No worries. And then, of course, they're tapping into their conversations and data.

FORBES: Yes. And unfortunately there, they've got a huge head start. But what I think it's eventually going to save us in the next few years, and we'll get real 5G out there. It's going to be a whole different architecture, massive new investments are going to be required. In that way, we can keep the Huawei's of the world out. Also underscores in terms of our dispute with China. Going after that CFO, going after specific companies, is a far more effective way of dealing with China than the tariffs, which end up hurting us not as much as China. But we get hurt too.

MCDOWELL: I'm curious, Steve, are enough of our allies standing alongside of us in terms of pushing back on Huawei and the use of that technology. Because, again, you've seen with -- which Maria was way ahead on in her interview with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, to crack down, and the message that we sent to Germany about we're not going to -- we're going to pull back on our intelligence share if you don't get in -- you get on board with us in terms of taking on Huawei. And then the grave danger of that poses to all other nations in terms of the espionage and the theft, are enough of our allies standing with us? Because they're (INAUDIBLE) few at this point.

FORBES: Well, I think they had to see how serious are we about this. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WRR-09R1-JBHT-D0R2-00000-00NYT: Facebook Data Deals Under Criminal Investigation; U.S. Grounds Boeing 737 Max; Actress Posts $1M Bond; USC To Boot Students; Huawei Heading To Court; Beto Announces 2020 Bid; Andrew Weissmann Will Soon Leave the Justice Department; Gambino Crime Boss Killed; Panther's Stadium Value; College Admission Scandal2019-03-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNYT: Facebook Data Deals Under Criminal Investigation; U.S. Grounds Boeing 737 Max; Actress Posts $1M Bond; USC To Boot Students; Huawei Heading To Court; Beto Announces 2020 Bid; Andrew Weissmann Will Soon Leave the Justice Department; Gambino Crime Boss Killed; Panther's Stadium Value; College Admission ScandalLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday, everybody, good morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, March 14th, your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. Facebook reportedly facing a criminal investigation now. At the central of the probe, the social media giant's data deals with other technology companies, it comes after a major outage at Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp last night.

Grounded now, President Trump is keeping all Boeing 737 Max jets in the U.S. parked as new reports say that the Ethiopian Airlines crash shows similarity to last year's Lion Air accident. There was evidence at the scene of that Ethiopian accident which caused the President to ground these planes.

A deadly and historic blizzard, bringing hurricane-force winds to the Central United States. More than 1,000 flights canceled at Denver's airport this morning. The storm is set to affect more than 70 million Americans. And out on bond, actress Lori Loughlin is posting $1 million in bond after appearing in court for her alleged role in the college admission scandal -- we have the very latest. There's a new report says that the scam was uncovered by accident. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: All right. Markets this morning are higher. Take a look, Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading this morning. The Dow Industrials right now up 50 points, as you see, a quarter of a percent. S&P 500 also higher by 4-1/2, and the NASDAQ up 17-1/4 points this morning. It looks like we will see a firmer opening this morning once the market is open.

Our top story this hour, Facebook is under fire again this morning. The company reportedly facing now a criminal investigation over controversial data-sharing deals. This, after a major outage hit Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp across the globe. Dagen McDowell, good morning to you. Dagen, what's your take?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That it's just incredible the way the story is developing and the recklessness that Facebook behaved with in terms of revealing people's data on the service. So, this is according to the New York times, that federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation into these data-sharing deals that Facebook struck with some of the world's largest technology companies. Again, shining an even brighter spotlight on the social media companies' business practices.

There's -- a grand jury in New York had subpoenaed records from at least two prominent makers of smart phones and other devices. This is according to reporting in the New York Times. These companies are among 150, including Amazon, Apple, Microsoft, and Sony, that at one point, cut data-sharing deals with Facebook. The agreement which were originally revealed in the New York Times let these companies see users' friends, contact information, other data about individuals, sometimes without consent.

Facebook says that it's phased out most of these partnerships over the last couple of years. This -- so this is a -- this is a grand jury of inquiry overseen by prosecutors. This is the eastern district of New York, but let's also talk about the federal trade commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission are looking into Facebook's behavior. Also, the Justice Department's securities fraud unit has been investigating. And this is in the northern district of California. The situation around the Cambridge Analytica data sharing. Remember Facebook back in -- I think it was 2011, signed a consent agreement with the Federal Trade Commission because it was sharing data in ways that deceit consumers, what's the fallout from that?

Meantime, Facebook was down yesterday, also Instagram, also WhatsApp, it owns all three of those companies. Down for at least 11 hours as of early Thursday, and the outage could force Facebook potentially to issue refunds to advertisers. And, of course, we were all just angry as you know what, that we couldn't get on to Instagram yesterday. Right, Maria? Back to you.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Yes, we were. But this criminal investigation is a big story. Wow.

MCDOWELL: Indeed. And again, where does it lead, and is Facebook now face -- remember, it's going to pivot its business to a more private communications. Well, nothing is -- nothing is private if you're operating on a Facebook platform. I think that the company has made that pretty clear.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because that's how they make money.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Advertising and data. All right, Dagen, we'll keep following that. Meanwhile, this is the big story as well, this morning, grounding the 737 Max altogether. The United States making this decision with the Federal Aviation Administration, after finding new data linking Sunday's Ethiopian Airlines crash and last October's Lion Air crash. President Trump commented on the move.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED: We're going to be issuing an emergency order of prohibition to ground all flights of the 737 Max 8 and the 738 Max 9, and the planes associated with that line. Planes that are in the air will be grounded if they are the 737 Max, will be grounded upon landing at the destination. The pilots have been notified. Airlines have been all notified. Airlines are agreeing with this, the safety of the American people and all people is our paramount concern.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Roman & Associates founder and CEO, Anthony Roman. Anthony, thanks very much for weighing in here.

ANTHONY ROMAN, FOUNDER & CEO, ROMAN & ASSOCIATES: Sure.

BARTIROMO: This is one of the most widely used planes across the country, right, and the world?

ROMAN: It is becoming one of the most widely used planes. And it's a fascinating aircraft with a 10 percent savings in fuel consumption. That's an enormous amount of money during global operations. It's also the best-selling aircraft in history, 5100 firm orders for Boeing. And Boeing is set to lose $25 billion in market value.

BARTIROMO: Right, it's already lost 25 billion market value since the Ethiopian crash happened. The stock is down about 10 percent. But what about this plane, what do we need to know about this plane? I mean, the fact that the FAA is now grounding all of the planes, travelers also are reacting to the 737's grounding. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I do trust airlines. I do understand that any aircraft or any kind of anything could have an issue at any time. It doesn't mean everything is bad, or -- I feel pretty safe flying.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Actually, I was flying back from Daytona Beach, American Airlines today. Did a couple of flights, and I wanted to make sure what plane I was getting on, because I've probably wouldn't have gotten on the Max.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There's a known safety concern, and certainly we're putting in the effort to figure it out before anything else happens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Anthony, what's your take on all of this?

ROMAN: Well, you know, pilots knew there was a problem, the FAA knew there was a problem, prior to Lion Air and immediately following Lion Air. The FAA reported in a worthiness directive, to of Boeing to redo some of the computer code on the MCAS and auto pilot system. That's not done unless they know there is some type of flaw in the system. But they have not reported to the public what that flaw may have been.

There were five pilot reports to the National Safety Reporting System. Identical problems to the Lion Air situation and similar to what we see on the satellite data in the oscillations in the takeoff phase, in Ethiopian air as well. And these captains, seasoned U.S. carrier captains reported to NASA that there were pitch oscillations, pitched down uncommanded actions by the aircraft, auto-throttles during the takeoff phase, not being in the correct position despite the input data placed in the computers by the pilot are verified to be correct. So, all sorts of problems with this aircraft.

The issue is, these airplanes are much more complicated than airplanes in the early 2000s, the 90s, and the 80s. These are highly-computerized machines, so not only are we dealing with more complexity in engines and systems, but now hundreds, if not millions of lines of code in these computer systems that have to be dealt with.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm. Because after the Lion Air crash, the CEO of Boeing told us that there were -- there was an issue that needed -- the pilots needed to be updated about, that the plane was upgraded, there was a change in some of the operations, the pilot needed to be aware of those. Is there -- is it beyond that that the pilots just need to be educated about this plane, or is it something bigger than that?

ROMAN: Well, usually, accident phases are a combination of issues. And the pilot, the lack of pilot awareness that this system was operating in the background, and the lack of pilot training to overcome, to recognize and overcome any anomalies in this system is just a failure. Basically, it had to be a cost-savings failure, because training time costs money, and the aviation industry is constantly trying, like all businesses, to drive its cost down. Not the best way to do it.

BARTIROMO: No, we'll be watching this. Obviously, a major impact to Boeing, but the safety of Americans is the administrations show its concern so they grounded all of them. Anthony, thanks very much for weighing in. Appreciate it very much. Anthony Roman joining us there.

Meanwhile, as you saw on the screen, Beto O'Rourke officially announcing his 2020 Presidential bid. We're going to talk about that this morning. And then there's this, deadly blizzard conditions in Colorado and across the country this morning. Cheryl Casone with all of that in headlines. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria, good morning. Nearly 1400 flights canceled at Denver International after a bomb cyclone hit the airport there. Look at these pictures, wind gusts as strong as 80 miles an hour. Elsewhere in Colorado, a police officer hit and killed while outside his vehicle, helping with the car that had skidded off of Interstate 76. Now, to Texas, small planes overturned like toys at a municipal airport by high winds. Strong winds also a major problem in New Mexico that caused a train to derail there. This is incredible.

And then, look at this, again, back to Texas, stunning videos, strong winds blew over a tractor trailer. It was -- it was unbelievable. We'll show it to you, hopefully, in a moment. It wasn't the only one, though, there's been reports of wind speeds up to 70 miles per hour, causing multiple trucks to blow over. This is happening in different parts of the country. No word on the conditions of the driver. Again, we'll get that video to you later in the show.

All right, the college admission scandal is now in federal court, actress Lori Loughlin posting $1 million bond in Los Angeles. She and her fashion designer husband are among 50 people facing fraud charges for allegedly paying bribes to get their daughters into colleges. One of the schools in the heart of the scandal, University of Southern California. The university says applicants who are connected to the admissions cheating scheme are going to be denied admission. A case-by-case review will be conducted for students who are already enrolled at USC and may be connected to the scheme.

And ABC News reports the FBI uncovered the $25 million nationwide college admissions cheating scandal by accident, while agents were working on unrelated securities fraud cases. The agents reportedly received a tip from somebody that was connected to the investigation about the alleged bribe, paid to the then-head women's soccer coach at Yale. Maria, this story just continues to fascinate the country, and a lot of kids that didn't get into those schools, I'm sure, are pretty angry as their parents are as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. With good reason. Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: Uh-hmm. You bet.

BARTIROMO: Breaking news, as we just heard, Beto O'Rourke makes his Presidential announcement official. We've got a lot more on that after a short break. Stay with us, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Big show this morning. Coming up right here, South Dakota Senator and Armed Services Committee member Mike Rounds is with us. Oregon Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member Greg Walden with some breaking news this morning from him. Former senior adviser to President George W. Bush, and Fox News Contributor Karl Rove joining us after an op-ed this morning. And former Presidential candidate and former Arkansas Governor, Mike Huckabee, joining us as well. Big three hours ahead. Don't miss a moment of it.

We want to talk right here about Huawei. It is in court today, lawyers for the Chinese telecom giant expected to appear in federal court later this morning, to answer charges that the company violated Iran trade tensions. Huawei is accused of dealing with Iran through a front company in Hong Kong. The company's Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou was arrested in Canada, accused of lying to banks about it. She's now awaiting extradition to the United States.

Joining the conversation this morning, Forbes Media Chairman and former Republican Presidential candidate Steve Forbes joining us here. Along with national security analyst and Fox News Contributor Morgan Ortagus. Great to see everybody this morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thanks. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: You're welcome. Yes, I mean, this Huawei story keeps getting worse. I know that they arrested her because of the Iran sanctions, and dealing with Iran. But there's also obviously, the privacy issues and the espionage that we've been talking about so much, Morgan.

ORTAGUS: Yes. And the Iran sanctions violations are very serious. I mean, what we've seen is over the past 10 years, probably, millions and millions of dollars paid by financial institutions, especially those based in New York as it relates to Iran sanctions. You're seeing most major banks on Wall Street have mediators and have people that are working on a daily basis to improve their systems, so they don't evade sanctions. So, to think that this is a sort of a one-off for this company is actually wrong. I mean, anybody in Wall Street can tell you that they're running scared of any sort of violation of Iran sanctions. It's quite serious.

BARTIROMO: I mean, I look at the Iran sanctions as one part of it, but really, the more -- the interesting part from my standpoint is the espionage issues, and the fact that it's gone across the world and to African countries and European countries, will set up your telecom infrastructure. No worries. And then, of course, they're tapping into their conversations and data.

FORBES: Yes. And unfortunately there, they've got a huge head start. But what I think it's eventually going to save us in the next few years, and we'll get real 5G out there. It's going to be a whole different architecture, massive new investments are going to be required. In that way, we can keep the Huawei's of the world out. Also underscores in terms of our dispute with China. Going after that CFO, going after specific companies, is a far more effective way of dealing with China than the tariffs, which end up hurting us not as much as China. But we get hurt too.

MCDOWELL: I'm curious, Steve, are enough of our allies standing alongside of us in terms of pushing back on Huawei and the use of that technology. Because, again, you've seen with -- which Maria was way ahead on in her interview with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, to crack down, and the message that we sent to Germany about we're not going to -- we're going to pull back on our intelligence share if you don't get in -- you get on board with us in terms of taking on Huawei. And then the grave danger of that poses to all other nations in terms of the espionage and the theft, are enough of our allies standing with us? Because they're (INAUDIBLE) few at this point.

FORBES: Well, I think they had to see how serious are we about this. It's one thing to say, oh, well, why don't you do this and that, but if you don't follow through one, they're not going to follow through. And I think our -- one of the things Huawei did was to make their stuff so cheap. It was a lost leader to get in there.

BARTIROMO: I was just going to say there's a cost issue here, right?

FORBES: And so all of these countries got this great bargain, 50 percent off, and now they're indebted.

ORTAGUS: Nothing is ever free.

BARTIROMO: Nothing is free. There's no free lunch.

MCDOWELL: Even small telecom providers here in the United States have used Huawei technology, and that is another later, another issue for this administration to tackle, because again, they're complaining about higher costs if they use different telecom equipment.

BARTIROMO: This is a really serious issue. And by the way, sidelining this issue is this potential trade deal with China. I think it's very ominous that we haven't heard yet, any specific date for Xi Jinping to meet with President Trump as they were expecting to do at the end of March in Mar-a-Lago. Where do these trade discussions stand now? It sure feels like China is pushing back on making any changes to the I.P. theft and the forced transfer of technology. All we've heard in terms of the give on China side is they're going to buy more stuff from the U.S. which is not going to cut it for a deal with the U.S.

FORBES: Well, the question is about enforcement is one of the things we want to do to be able to put tariffs on Chinese goods and they can't put tariffs on ours if we think they're engage in violations, the Chinese are not going to go along with that. And so, well, what you have here is a game of chicken, and I think the key thing is, if we continue to do what we did against Huawei and some other companies, that's the message to get across.

MCDOWELL: And the message is to punish bad actors but not punish companies like, say, European automakers that make cars here in the U.S. that create U.S. jobs. It's important to point out that we've heard earlier this week that the momentum seems to be slipping for auto import tariff, something that President Trump has talked about a lot, a 25 percent levy potentially on car imports to the United States.

FORBES: Yes. That's so called Section 232. If that came, then that would devastate the global economy.

MCDOWELL: And it would hurt U.S. jobs. These are companies across the south, Mercedes, BMW, Volkswagen, that have been real job creators in the United States.

FORBES: Yes, they have.

MCDOWELL: And they're actually -- they're helping our trade deficit by exporting cars overseas that they make here.

FORBES: BMW is ready to export 100,000 vehicles they make in South Carolina. What's not to like?

MCDOWELL: Exactly. So, that's -- this is a positive sign. Punish the bad actors but people who actually create jobs here in the United States who are on our side, ease up.

BARTIROMO: All right. Let's take a short break on that note. And when we come back, a modern day mob hit. The alleged boss of the Gambino crime family was gunned down outside of his home. We've got the details coming up right after this. And then, Gary Cohn speaking out, President Trump's former economic adviser says the President is "desperate" to sign a deal with China, that's next, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures are mixed right now, pretty good reversal in the last 20 minutes, Dow Industrials now down four points, the S&P down a quarter, and the NASDAQ is up six. Market uncertainty this morning. There's some uncertainty obviously over Britain's exit from the European Union as well as a deal between the U.S. and China. Now, Gary Cohn, former economic adviser to President Trump spoke out on a deal with China in a new interview, watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GARY COHN, FORMER ECONOMIC ADVISER TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: I think the U.S. is desperate right now for an agreement.

STEPHEN DUBNER, HOST, FREAKONOMICS: An agreement or headline?

COHN: The President needs a win. The only big open issue right now that he could claim as a big win, that he hope would have a big impact on the stock market would be Chinese resolution.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: A new report now says that the U.S. and China are pushing back a meeting between the President and Xi Jinping to at least April of this year. Joining us right now is Russell Investments Senior Portfolio Manager Kevin Divney. Kevin, it's good to have you on the program this morning.

KEVIN DIVNEY, SENIOR PORTFOLIO MANAGER, RUSSELL INVESTMENTS: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: How important is that meeting and this deal between the two countries for the markets?

DIVNEY: The market's pricing in that something is going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DIVNEY: And if you saw last earnings season, the thing that was hurting U.S. earnings was Chinese exposure. The Chinese economy is hurting much more than the U.S. economy, and it seems as if the market is shrugging off any kind of headline risk, and they're looking to what's going on the -- what's going on the ground in China. So, the market is pricing it in, and there's probably some more risk to the upside here. And a lot of risk to the downside if something doesn't happen.

BARTIROMO: And then you've got Brexit, Parliament shuts down the latest deal for Britain's exit from the European Union. The M.P.s voted yesterday to reject the no-deal exit under any circumstances. Prime Minister Theresa May expected to try one more plan this week before a potential vote to delay Britain's exit from the European Union, is that a factor for you, for markets?

DIVNEY: Fundamentally, European economies are decoupling from the U.S., who see PMIs almost getting to negative territory. You see earnings decelerate, you see spending coming down. U.S. companies are growing and they're still investing. So, I think investors have hedged that away and looking at the momentum of the U.S. economy and the labor market here. So, it's being compartmentalize, and from an allocation perspective, I think a lot of people are just looking at the U.S. robustness right now.

FORBES: Can the U.S. stay robust if China and Japan and Europe, Germany, especially are still in the water?

DIVNEY: I think so. There's two main drivers we're looking at, one, the labor market is really strong right now. You see labor force participation from that really high earning, high spending group, 25 to 54, has been gone from 80 percent of its low three years ago to 83 percent. Also on earnings, if you look at this market expansion, a lot of the expansion has been driven by the profit margin expansion. So earnings have grown, we have the 10-year anniversary last night at the bull market. But most Bull Markets have been driving about a third by profit growth. In this expansion, something about two thirds of profit growth. So, even last earnings season, we saw profits flatten and they may go down a bit, but we're at peak margins, and the topline sales expectations for the U.S. have not been revised down meaningfully. Everybody knows earnings have going into 2019, but the topline is still around five or six percent --

FORBES: Are you worried about the slowness in the first quarter in the U.S. economy, or is that just a blip?

DIVNEY: It's reminding me of what happened in 2015, 2016, which was somewhat fascinating, because you saw an earnings contraction and an earnings expansion after that, for the first time without a recessions since the postwar period. So, I think companies adapt and also the -- people coming back into the labor force is one of the big stories, I think people aren't really getting, people are coming back in, they were underemployed or unemployed, and that momentum continues.

BARTIROMO: We're not going to get the profit growth that we saw last year this year, that's for sure. So, that's a worry that we're really are seeing a slowdown in the U.S., Europe on top of that, China on top of that.

That's the plan right now. But lots of questions, of course, about Tesla, how it's dealing with its debt. Those questions continue. That company frankly in turmoil as it prepares to roll out this new Crossover, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Gerri. Thank you. Gerri Willis there on Wall Street pushing back on the Green New Deal. Eleven house members are urging Speaker Nancy Pelosi to hold hearings on the agenda championed by freshman Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Joining me now is Oregon Congressman and House Energy and Commerce Committee member, Greg Walden. Congressman, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

REP. GREG WALDEN (R-OR), HOUSE ENERGY AND COMMERCE COMMITTEE: Hey, good morning, Maria. You got it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I've got the letter in my hand from many of you -- from you and many of your colleagues who have signed on on the bottom line here. You're urging the chairman to put hearings on this. Why? What's the point?

WALDEN: Well, we know from history that the last time this happened, Speaker Pelosi told the National Association of CountiesCongress had to pass Obamacare so we can find out what's in it. We don't want that to happen here. Look, the American people have a right to know what's in the Green New Deal, the effect it will have on their energy prices, on climate, on jobs. The AFL-CIO yesterday came out and said millions of workers in America would be adversely affected by the Green New Deal. Independent think tanks have said it caused out a $93 trillion would increase your energy bills by 22 percent.

We have a right to know what the left is doing here, what the Socialist Democrats are doing here, and my fear is they're going to cram through Congress like they've done other legislation, not give due process, not give hearings, and all we're asking for is let's have a hearing on this legislation.

BARTIROMO: No, we've been poking --

WALDEN: Roll out your plan.

BARTIROMO: -- holes in this plan from the get-go, on this program --

WALDEN: Right.

BARTIROMO: Because of the cost. As you said, $93 trillion. And also because, well, frankly, it doesn't make any sense to do away with fossil fuels within 10 years. We've have spoken with scientists and it's -- it can't be done basically.

WALDEN: That's right.

BARTIROMO: So do you think that a hearing would educate the people? I mean the pushback that we've gotten Dagen, right, is that this is just broad strokes. This is just an idea.

MCDOWELL: Yes, broad strokes like let's get rid of all --

WALDEN: Well, yes, right.

MCDOWELL: -- fossil fuels in this country.

WALDEN: Right.

MCDOWELL: And livestock --

MCDOWELL: Which, by the way, if --

WALDEN: And airplanes and everything else.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

WALDEN: And these are pretty radical broad strokes, by the way.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALDEN: This is pretty off the canvas stuff. And there would be policy that would follow, we know that. Look, we're open --

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, let me bring Dagen in. Let me bring Dagen in because we've both been really been poking holes in this from the get-go, Dagen.

WALDEN: Good.

BARTIROMO: How do you see it?

MCDOWELL: It would hurt the poor in America --

WALDEN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- and lower income Americans more than anybody else. We use fossil fuel, we use gasoline and natural gas because there are plentiful in the United States and inexpensive, number one. We are not a nation, given its size, that we can get around places on light rail. We saw the boondoggle out in California --

WALDEN: That's right. That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- which, again, has basically -- most of it has been shelved, the light rail project, the high speed trains there. Also, we're a leader in reducing emissions on the global stage.

WALDEN: That's right.

MCDOWELL: In the world in part because of natural gas. Emissions since 2005 have fallen 30 percent coming out of electric power plants because of the use of natural gas. So I don't -- again, did she cook this up at the bar late one night before she won her congressional seat after a little too much tequila? I don't know.

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Congressman?

WALDEN: Well, I -- that's all spot-on. By the way, we have a housing crisis in my state and in my district, and this would drive up the cost of housing. You see what's happening in California with some of their radical ideas. The Civil Liberties Union and others are suing because the impact it has on the poor to drive up the cost of housing. Look, we have innovative ideas to reduce carbon emissions and deal with climate change as Republicans. We want an opportunity to put our ideas forward. , and to your point, by leading on energy development and discovery, by leading on innovation like battery storage, by putting forward new nuclear technologies, we can make the math add up but their math doesn't add up when you're going a hundred percent renewables in 10 years.

They want to get rid of livestock, airplanes. My district would stretch from the Atlantic to Ohio. There's no high speed rail going to get me home and around that district. And livestock's our number two ag commodity in my district and they want to get rid of that.

MCDOWELL: Just to --

WALDEN: I mean this -- none of this adds up.

MCDOWELL: Just to be clear -- I just want to be clear about something. I'm not making fun of this woman's job. We've all worked at some -- at one -- at one point --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- tending bar --

BARTIROMO: I was the coat check girl.

MCDOWELL: -- wait -- right. Waiting tables. We're not making fun of that. But we are making -- we are calling out somebody who's has gotten a lot of attention because one, she's an attractive woman and she's young and she knows how to use social media very well and personally, as a woman, I want her to be better. I want her to be smarter. I don't want her to spout nonsense, things that are not true about the unemployment rate in this country.

WALDEN: Right.

MCDOWELL: And how, you know, how many hours a week the average American works.

WALDEN: Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Just learn some facts.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but let's be clear. Nancy Pelosi is not going to put this down for a vote. I mean Congressman, your letter is urging the speaker to do that, but she's already locked arms with AOC.

WALDEN: We're asking for hearings. We're asking for hearings. Let's take a look at it. And what you haven't touched on is the fact the Green New Deal also includes a full government takeover of your health care.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

WALDEN: Read the data today coming out of England about wait times for cancer patients to get treatment. They're not meeting any of their mandates, any of their goals here. And we don't want long wait times in America and that's $32 trillion, a complete government takeover.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible.

WALDEN: And so there -- this is much more than just climate contained in the socialist manifesto. And I think Americans have the right to know and as members of Congress, I don't want this thing pulled up quickly and voted on without us having a chance to go through it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

WALDEN: And that's what we're asking for.

BARTIROMO: Well, you make a good point.

WALDEN: Can't we just have hearings?

BARTIROMO: You think you'll have the hearing? You think you'll have hearings on all of this?

WALDEN: I certainly hope so.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

WALDEN: You know, the Energy and Commerce Committee has a record of bipartisan work in these matters and I think there's an opportunity we should have a hearing.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, thank you so much for joining us this morning.

WALDEN: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Congressman Greg Walden there. Breaking news on Tesla, the company is announcing Zachary Kirkhorn the new Chief Financial Officer. Company also naming a new Chief Accounting Officer. This just coming out right now with these new appointments. CFO and new accounting officer at Tesla, stock is up, better than one percent right now. We'll take a short break. When we come back, Boeing is battling a major crisis. The U.S. has grounded all Boeing 737 Max aircrafts. Stuart Varney weighs in on that when we come back.

Then the big business of gaming, EA Games reportedly paying the world's top gamer a million dollars to play and promote the launch of Apex Legends. But first, a special update from the Tennis Channel right now.

DANI KLUPENGER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, guys, welcome back to another Tennis Channel court report. For FOX Business, I'm Dani Klupenger. The Superstars came out to play on day eight at the BNP Paribas Open. Roger Federer continued his excellent run off form as he look for a record sixth title in the desert. The 20-time major champion eased past Great Britain's Kyle Edmund in straight sets to punch his ticket into the elite eight.

Federer moves on to face Poland's Hubert Hurkacz for a spot in the final four. Earlier, Rafael Nadal barely broke a sweat as he dispatched Philipp Krajinovic to reach the quarters. The Spaniard closing out the impressive win at 6-4 after just under an hour and a half on court. And don't forget, you can watch all the action from the California Desert on Tennis Channel. Our live daily coverage hits the air at 1:00 p.m. Eastern. I'm Dani Klupenger.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well, the Federal Aviation Administration is grounding all Boeing 737 Max 8 airplanes in the U.S. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & CO." to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. I'm trying to put myself in the position of being an airline which has one of these Max jets on order. After all, there are 4,000 of these jets that are on order from Boeing, so you got airlines all around the world waiting to take delivery. Some of them are about to take delivery. What do they do? Here they've ordered a plane, which is now not allowed to fly. Do they take delivery? Do they have some kind of financial accommodation with Boeing? And this is not going to be fixed very quickly. The black box in the Ethiopian crash has been taken to Paris. It was badly damaged. They have special equipment there to get inside the thing and find out what happened.

That's going to take weeks, maybe months. So, it's a very long time before you find out exactly what happened, what is the problem with these jets and how do you fix it. In other words, you've got all these orders that are going out there and will the airlines take delivery? What's going to happen? It's the great unknown and I think it's a huge negative for Boeing.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: That's what I got to say.

BARTIROMO: huge, huge negative, for sure. I think, Stuart, this company is down 25 billion in market value --

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- just since the Ethiopian crash.

VARNEY: Yes. Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Pretty incredible. We've seen an impact, we'll probably see a continued one.

VARNEY: I have no idea the financial impact on Boeing.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: But in the immediate term, there is going to be a negative financial impact.

BARTIROMO: For sure. Yes.

VARNEY: How it works out, don't know.

BARTIROMO: I know you'll have more in about 10 minutes. Stu, we'll see you then. Thanks so much. "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart at 9:00 a.m. Eastern.

First though, college cheat scheme. Actress Lori Loughlin is posting $1 million bond after appearing in court for alleged bribery to get her daughter into an elite university. We've got the very latest there. And then game on, the world's top computer gamer, Ninja, reportedly making $1 million to promote the launch of Apex Legends. The business of gaming after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More to that college admissions scandal. Lori Loughlin released on a $1 million bond and is scheduled to face a Boston judge with Felicity Huffman on March 29th. CEO Gregory Abbott and his wife, Marcia, also reportedly bought their daughter's way into school. Their son, Malcolm, coming to their defense while smoking pot on the streets of New York and promoting his mixtape, saying this, "They're blowing this whole thing out of proportion. I believe everyone has a right to go to college, man."

Joining me right now, reaction, is FOX News Contributor and "GREG GUTFELD SHOW" Correspondent, Kat Timpf, Former Obama Campaign Adviser and Democratic Strategist, Robin Biro, Dion Rabouin, Axios Markets Newsletter Author, and FOX News Contributor and National Security Analyst, Morgan Ortagus. Great to see you, guys. Well, I mean just the idea that he's on the streets of New York smoking marijuana in the face of this, what is he thinking?

DION RABOUIN, AXIOS MARKETS NEWSLETTER AUTHOR: That's not even a misdemeanor anymore, right? Now in de Blasio's New York, you know, that's just like getting a traffic ticket. So, hey, maybe his mixtape is hot, Maria.

BARTIROMO: No, it's still --

RABOUIN: Maybe it's --

BARTIROMO: -- not legal in New York for --

RABOUIN: No, no, it's not legal, but it's basically like getting a traffic ticket at this point.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ORTAGUS: It's gross. I'm so sick of smelling weed.

ROBIN BIRO, FORMER OBAMA CAMPAIGN ADVISER AND DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: I was just going to say I can't walk down the street without getting caught in a cloud of weed smoke.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean it's probably going to go -- to go legal at some point. But the real point is it's not and this guy is sort of sticking his nose, you know, sticking his finger in the hurt by doing this.

BIRO: Yes.

KAT TIMPF, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: This is what happens when you have parents who will get you out of anything and everything.

BARTIROMO: Right,

TIMPF: And who will do anything for you. They make you so entitled --

BIRO: Entitlement.

TIMPF: -- that this guy is saying, "Oh, I'm going to be a rap star. I bet you -- " I mean I've not heard -- and I've not heard his CD, but I do not plan to listen to it.

ORTAGUS: Mixtape.

RABOUIN: His mixtape -- his mixtape might be hot.

BARTIROMO: His mixtape --

TIMPF: I just -- this is what happens when you're so entitled and you know your parents will get you out of anything. This is the way that you behave.

BARTIROMO: I thought --

BIRO: I'm not buying that mixtape at the gas station.

TIMPF: No. I hope his parents didn't spend money on him getting into college.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

ORTAGUS: They probably buy him weed.

RABOUIN: I think they did. I think this one --

BARTIROMO: So do you -- do you think all the students involved are either going to be pulled out or it's too late for that? I mean they're not going to -- they're obviously not going to let anyone in who attempted to cheat.

BIRO: Like I said, pull them out.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BIRO: And send them to military school. As a vet, I'm all for it.

RABOUIN: Well, this scandal's been going on for years. I think they tracked it back to 2011 to 2018. So, some of these kids I think are still in college. Some of these kids probably have their degrees already and have moved on. Maybe they have jobs in, you know, prestigious firms. Who knows? Obviously some are out selling mixtapes on the street and smoking marijuana, but, you know, these kids are -- a lot of them I think have probably already graduated and moved on and really what do you do? You can't take the degree back.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I wonder how the students did in school given the fact they did pay their way in. Hey, how about this? Pay for play. Fortnite, great Tyler Blevins, known as Ninja, reportedly made $1 million for promoting the competition, Apex Legends. So, he's being paid to promote this.

TIMPF: What a life, to get paid for playing videogames. Everyone else plays videogames to the detriment of their career.

BARTIROMO: Right. Yes.

TIMPF: I think that good for him, wonderful, but I don't think kids should look at this and say, "See, mom and dad?"

BIRO: That's what I want to do.

TIMPF: "I don't got to do my homework. I'm going to be a millionaire by playing videogames."

BARTIROMO: If it works for him.

BIRO: But hey, if Kendall Jenner can get a quarter of a million dollars for one post on Instagram to promote the Fyre Festival, why not?

RABOUIN: And this is from the market's perspective, this was really a great thing for EA. They were falling behind other video game makers. Fortnite has really sucked all the air out of the videogame space and this really got EA back on top. I think they've got about 50 million users playing this game right now, which was the biggest launch in I think a long time, at least since Fortnite's been out. And their stock has really responded as a result, so.

ORTAGUS: I'm a capitalist. I'm all for people making money, whether it's through promoting videogames, reality T.V., like, you know, whatever.

RABOUIN: Yes.

ORTAGUS: Whatever, as long as you're making money, I'm not into socialism and free everything.

RABOUIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, speaking of making money, listen to this. There are now more wealthy households in the United States equivalent to the entire population of Sweden. Last year, more than 10.2 million households saw a net worth of $1 million to $5 million breaking a new record, according to a spectrum group survey. Pretty good stuff that you're seeing --

BIRO: Awesome.

BARTIROMO: -- so many millionaires in the U.S. and people lift out of poverty. That's capitalism.

TIMPF: Yes. Absolutely. It's a great thing. It's so hip to sort of demonize people for being successful, but that's not what this country is supposed to be out -- about. I don't understand where we reached the point where successful equals bad.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TIMPF: And, no, that's a great thing. It's a wonderful thing.

BARTIROMO: So what do you think about this whole debate about capitalism versus socialism? Good op-ed in The Journal today by Dan Henninger, socialism, yes, be afraid.

TIMPF: Uh-hmm.

BARTIROMO: Your thoughts. Dion.

RABOUIN: Look, I don't know that socialism is coming to America. And, again, there are lots of different types of socialism. There's -- you've got Bernie on the left saying he wants Democratic Socialism, which it's important to point out is very different from what's happening in Venezuela and the situation there. You've also got places like Norway that have socialism, you've got Chile who had a socialist president. So, what that means is there's a lot of different things. I think a lot of people are quick to point at something and call it socialism.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's be clear --

RABOUIN: It's a broad spectrum.

BARTIROMO: -- this is federal -- this is a federal takeover of certain industries. And that's what Medicare For All is.

RABOUIN: But that's not what --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's what this Green New Deal is. So, these are socialist policies.

BIRO: I'm a little interested to see Nancy Pelosi herself pushing back on some of these. Basically with the Green Deal she kind of said, "Yes, that's cute," and just moved on. So, as a Democrat myself I was a little but relieved because I'm scared. I'm more of the, you know, I'm a Southern Democrat so this socialism stuff kind of scares me a little bit, honestly.

TIMPF: There's no doubt that the polling shows that Millennials and Generation Z are more in favor of socialism than any other generation.

BIRO: Right.

TIMPF: I just don't think they totally understand what it is. They think it's wearing like a Che Guevara T-shirt.

BARTIROMO: I think you're right. Great Millennial panel, guys. Thank you so much.

ORTAGUS: Thank you.

RABOUIN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Appreciate it. Kat Timpf, Robin Biro, Dion Rabouin, and Morgan Ortagus. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Great show. Dagen, Steve, Morgan, thank you.

FORBES: Thank you.

ORTAGUS: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Love you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Have a great day, everybody. "VARNEY & CO." begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: All right. Good morning, Maria.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:6067-KHV1-DXKX-0538-00000-00NYT Fantasizes About 'Secret Deal' Between Trump and Zuckerberg2020-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNYT Fantasizes About 'Secret Deal' Between Trump and Zuckerberg

Jun 22, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) The liberal media is building its own web of conspiracy theories about President Donald Trump's re-election campaign. The New York Times seems to think he's made a deal with Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg as part of the grand plan.Times media columnist Ben Smith speculated [1]about a deal that might have been made between Trump and Zuckerberg at a dinner that took place in November 2019. Smith claimed that he had received details from unnamed Facebook and White House officials about the details of that dinner.

Of course, Smith qualified his queries, stating, '[I]t's hard to imagine that anyone certainly not Mr. Zuckerberg would be dumb enough to make a secret deal with a president known for keeping neither secrets nor deals.'The piece painted a dark picture for Facebook: 'Democrats hate and distrust [Facebook] because they spread right-wing misinformation and helped elect Donald Trump.' Meanwhile, the conservative problems with Facebook were whitewashed: 'Republicans hate and distrust [Facebook] because they're run by California liberals and delete some right-wing speech.'Smith wondered what agreement the two reached during that dinner, saying, 'Mr. Zuckerberg needs, and appears to be getting, a pass both on angry tweets from the president and the serious threats of lawsuits and regulation that face other big tech companies.'Times tech reporter Cecilia Kang threw in her two cents, asking in a tweet[2]: '[I]t's clear it's also playing the short game on Trump. Where does that leave FB w/ a potential Biden 2020 win?'An early Facebook investor, Roger McNamee, stated in the piece, 'Trump needs Facebook's thumb on the scale to win this election.' And a former Democratic policy communications Facebook employee, Nu Wexler, was quoted as saying, '[C]ompanies should be worried about Democrats as well. The days of just keeping the president happy are over.'NBC Senior Media Reporter Dylan Byers noted in his daily 'Byers Market' newsletter[3], 'Fair to wonder, but Smith doesn't actually have any evidence of a secret deal.' urn:contentItem:6067-CFS1-F03R-N4C2-00000-00NYT Fantasizes About 'Secret Deal' Between Trump and Zuckerberg2020-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNYT Fantasizes About 'Secret Deal' Between Trump and ZuckerbergCorinne Weaver

Jun 22, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) The liberal media is building its own web of conspiracy theories about President Donald Trump's re-election campaign. The New York Times seems to think he's made a deal with Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg as part of the grand plan.Times media columnist Ben Smith speculated [1]about a deal that might have been made between Trump and Zuckerberg at a dinner that took place in November 2019. Smith claimed that he had received details from unnamed Facebook and White House officials about the details of that dinner.

Of course, Smith qualified his queries, stating, '[I]t's hard to imagine that anyone — certainly not Mr. Zuckerberg — would be dumb enough to make a secret deal with a president known for keeping neither secrets nor deals.'The piece painted a dark picture for Facebook: 'Democrats hate and distrust [Facebook] because they spread right-wing misinformation and helped elect Donald Trump.' Meanwhile, the conservative problems with Facebook were whitewashed: 'Republicans hate and distrust [Facebook] because they're run by California liberals and delete some right-wing speech.'Smith wondered what agreement the two reached during that dinner, saying, 'Mr. Zuckerberg needs, and appears to be getting, a pass both on angry tweets from the president and the serious threats of lawsuits and regulation that face other big tech companies.'Times tech reporter Cecilia Kang threw in her two cents, asking in a tweet[2]: '[I]t's clear it's also playing the short game on Trump. Where does that leave FB w/ a potential Biden 2020 win?'An early Facebook investor, Roger McNamee, stated in the piece, 'Trump needs Facebook's thumb on the scale to win this election.' And a former Democratic policy communications Facebook employee, Nu Wexler, was quoted as saying, '[C]ompanies should be worried about Democrats as well. The days of just keeping the president happy are over.'NBC Senior Media Reporter Dylan Byers noted in his daily 'Byers Market' newsletter[3], 'Fair to wonder, but Smith doesn't actually have any evidence of a secret deal.' urn:contentItem:606C-XV61-JCMN-Y08Y-00000-00NYT Fantasizes About 'Secret Deal' Between Trump And Zuckerberg2020-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNYT Fantasizes About 'Secret Deal' Between Trump And ZuckerbergPA Pundits - International

Jun 23, 2020( PA Pundits: http://papundits.wordpress.com/ Delivered by Newstex) By Corinne Weaver ~ The liberal media is building its own web of conspiracy theories about President Donald Trump's re-election campaign. The New York Times seems to think he's made a deal with Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg as part of the grand plan. Times media columnist Ben Smith speculated [1]about a deal that might have been made between Trump and Zuckerberg at a dinner that took place in November 2019. Smith claimed that he had received details from unnamed Facebook and White House officials about the details of that dinner.

Of course, Smith qualified his queries, stating, '[I]t's hard to imagine that anyone — certainly not Mr. Zuckerberg — would be dumb enough to make a secret deal with a president known for keeping neither secrets nor deals.' The piece painted a dark picture for Facebook: 'Democrats hate and distrust [Facebook] because they spread right-wing misinformation and helped elect Donald Trump.' Meanwhile, the conservative problems with Facebook were whitewashed: 'Republicans hate and distrust [Facebook] because they're run by California liberals and delete some right-wing speech.' Smith wondered what agreement the two reached during that dinner, saying, 'Mr. Zuckerberg needs, and appears to be getting, a pass both on angry tweets from the president and the serious threats of lawsuits and regulation that face other big tech companies.'Times tech reporter Cecilia Kang threw in her two cents, asking in a tweet[2]: '[I]t's clear it's also playing the short game on Trump. Where does that leave FB w/ a potential Biden 2020 win?' An early Facebook investor, Roger McNamee, stated in the piece, 'Trump needs Facebook's thumb on the scale to win this election.' And a former Democratic policy communications Facebook employee, Nu Wexler, was quoted as saying, '[C]ompanies should be worried about Democrats as well. The days of just keeping the president happy are over.' NBC Senior Media Reporter Dylan Byers noted in his daily 'Byers Market' newsletter[3], 'Fair to wonder, but Smith doesn't actually have any evidence of a secret deal.' Corinne Weaver[4] is a staff writer for MRC TechWatch[5] and she works as a senior analyst for the Media Research Center at the NewsBusters[6] site. As the Joe and Betty Anderlik Fellow, her coverage on tech censorship, media bias, and pro-life issues have been cited by many in the conservative movement. Read more Great Articles at NewsBusters[7] . http://newsbusters.org/[8] [ 1]:   https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/21/business/media/facebook-donald-trump-mark-zuckerberg.html?smid=tw-share [ 2]:   https://twitter.com/ceciliakang/status/1274867570676563968 [ 3]:   https://link.nbcnews.com/view/5e21b1c67e55546a62206d1ecbg8s.7ky/54c19953 [ 4]:   https://www.newsbusters.org/author/corinne-weaver [ 5]:   https://www.newsbusters.org/techwatch [ 6]:   http://newsbusters.org/ [ 7]:   http://newsbusters.org/ [ 8]:   http://newsbusters.org/

urn:contentItem:5X11-N841-DY7M-135R-00000-00NYTimes Analysis: Regulators Have Different Concerns About Four "Big Tech" Players2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisWASHINGTON NEWSNYTimes Analysis: Regulators Have Different Concerns About Four "Big Tech" Players

Writing that although "the four firms are lumped together so often that they have become known as Big Tech," the New York Times (9/8, Nicas, Weise, Isaac, 18.61M) says Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google have key differences that will impact how they may be regulated, both by the US and abroad. Amazon and Google have faced breakup calls, while antitrust focus against Apple is focused on its tight control over its smartphone App Store. Facebook faces questions about both privacy and alleged monopolistic practices.

urn:contentItem:5H2K-DRS1-F03R-N0PM-00000-00NY Times biz desk hires Kang as tech regulation reporter2015-10-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNY Times biz desk hires Kang as tech regulation reporterChris Roush

Oct 03, 2015( Talking Biz News: http://www.talkingbiznews.com Delivered by Newstex) <nl/>   http://talkingbiznews.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/KangCeciliaTE122-225x150.jpgNew York Times business editor Dean Murphy sent out the following announcement Friday afternoon:<nl/>

<nl/>The convergence of technology, media and telecommunications is reshaping business everywhere, but perhaps nowhere are the consequences more pressing than in Washington. We're pleased to announce that this fast-moving beat will soon be in the expert hands of Cecilia Kang, who for the past seven years has covered regulatory, legislative and tech policy issues at The Washington Post.<nl/> Cecilia, the Post's senior technology correspondent, has written about net neutrality, online privacy, the on-demand economy, the digital divide, education technology, and much more. She wrote a series of stories about big tech companies allowing in-app purchases by children, which spurred an FTC investigation, charges last year against Apple, Google and Amazon for deceptive practices, and a tightening of rules governing those purchases.<nl/> Upshot's Neil Irwin, who worked with Cecilia at The Post, describes her as 'a stone-cold pro' who has owned her beat by 'combining subject area knowledge, sourcing and hard work.'<nl/> Cecilia will be based in Washington and report to the tech cluster, while also working closely with Bill Brink from media and Elisabeth Bumiller from the Washington bureau<nl/> Cecilia has been at The Post since 2006, previously working at the Seattle Post-Intelligencer, the San Jose Mercury News (where our own Vindu Goel was her editor) and AP-Dow Jones in South Korea, where she covered the Asian financial crisis as both an editor and a reporter.<nl/> A child of Korean immigrants, Cecilia says her first job was to fill ketchup bottles and napkin dispensers at the family's burger joint in Seattle. She was promoted when the family took over an ice cream shop and assigned Cecilia to the frozen banana dipping station. But her career in food ended abruptly, she says, when another employee (her sister) said she found a hair in the chopped nut tray.<nl/> 'Journalism has worked out much better,' says Cecilia, who, to this day, disputes the hair allegation.<nl/> She starts next month.<nl/>

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W1H-HH31-F03R-N206-00000-00NYTimes calls for William Barr to investigate Apple2019-05-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNYTimes calls for William Barr to investigate AppleSteven M. Peters

May 03, 2019( 24/7 Wall St.: http://www.247wallst.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Calls status quo at the App Store 'untenable.' From Why Does Apple Control Its Competitors?

,[1]the lead editorial in Friday's New York Times. Of the 17 most popular screen-time and parental-control apps in the App Store, 11 have been removed or restricted by Apple. The app makers believe they are being punished for competing with Apple's own screen-time control tools, or worse, for weaning people off Apple devices. Many of the apps had more stringent controls than Apple's in-house alternatives. Apple says that the applications — specifically, the parental-control apps — were removed because of their use of Mobile Device Management, a technology that gave third parties access to information such as 'user location, app use, email accounts, camera permissions and browsing history.' In other words, Apple says it removed the apps to protect the privacy of the children and parents who installed them. The actions by Apple highlight the inherent tension in the company's fierce control over its mobile operating system: On the one hand, the closed environment is a boon to consumer privacy because the company has the leverage to insist upon it; on the other hand, that environment fosters a kind of monopoly Even if we take Apple at its word that it was only protecting the privacy and security of its users by removing screen-time and parental-control apps, the state of the app marketplace is troubling. Why is a company — with no mechanism for democratic oversight — the primary and most zealous guardian of user privacy and security? Why is one company in charge of vetting what users can or cannot do on their phones, especially when that company also makes apps that compete in a marketplace that it controls? The status quo is untenable. It's time for American regulators to take a good hard look at app stores and mobile operating systems. It might be time for another United States v. Microsoft. My take: Or maybe not. The United States might have bigger fish to fry right now. See also: Who's to blame for Apple 'Screen Time' debacle?[2] Elizabeth Warren's big tech breakup plan spares Apple or does it?[3] https://www.ped30.com/247wallst-promo/ [ 1]:   https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/02/opinion/apple-app-store-iphone.html?emc=edit_th_190503...todaysheadlines...d=16380503 [ 2]:   https://www.ped30.com/2019/04/29/apple-screen-time-debacle/ [ 3]:   https://www.ped30.com/2019/03/08/elizabeth-warrens-tech-breakup-apple/

urn:contentItem:5RTJ-0KH1-JCMN-Y3ST-00000-00NY Times hires Bloomberg's Satariano to cover tech in Europe2018-03-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisNY Times hires Bloomberg's Satariano to cover tech in EuropeChris Roush

Mar 07, 2018( Talking Biz News: http://www.talkingbiznews.com Delivered by Newstex) Adam SatarianoAdrienne Carter, deputy business editor of The New York Times, sent out the following announcement on Wednesday:We're thrilled to announce that Adam Satariano is coming aboard as our technology correspondent based in London, where he will cover Europe's vast technology scene. Adam joins us from Bloomberg, where he was a reporter for 11 years, first in San Francisco covering beats including the environment and the entertainment business, before transitioning to report on Silicon Valley's technology industry.

In 2016, he moved to London to cover European tech for Bloomberg. Prior to Bloomberg, he worked in Washington for Congressional Quarterly. In his technology coverage, Adam has chronicled the ups-ups-ups of Apple when the company was in its iPhone growth phase, and its transition into the post-Steve Jobs era. He also covered emerging tech trends such as the daily fantasy sports industry[1], how A.I. is being adopted in finance such as at hedge funds[2], and the flameouts of high profile start-ups[3]. More recently, he wrote about how Silicon Valley executives are themselves grappling with the issue of tech addiction[4]. Adam wrote for both Bloomberg News and Bloomberg Businessweek, as well as appearing on T.V. and working on videos and podcasts. (He turned his own unfortunate moment of internet infamy into a podcast episode[5] about the deterioration of online privacy.) He joins at an important moment for Europe and tech. The region is setting the regulatory pace in crimping the power of big tech companies, with rules around data privacy and rulings on antitrust. Other countries are now increasingly looking to Europe as a model for tech policies. And the region is also a hotbed for A.I. innovation, 5G and cybersecurity developments. Adam, a native of the San Francisco Bay Area and a graduate of UC Santa Cruz, lives with his wife, Nickie, and their two sons in south London. Despite being 5,000 miles away, he remains a committed fan of the San Francisco Giants and the 49ers. Please extend a warm welcome to Adam, who starts soon. [ 1]: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-15/the-growing-world-of-moneymaking-fantasy-sports [ 2]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-09-27/the-massive-hedge-fund-betting-on-ai [ 3]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-11-11/a-would-be-uber-rival-s-250-million-taxi-ride-to-nowhere [ 4]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-05/tech-diets-catch-on-with-apple-executives-facebook-billionaires-and-googlers [ 5]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-14/here-s-what-to-do-if-you-find-an-embarrassing-video-of-yourself-on-instagram
