Priebus; Game Of `Survivor?'; Uber's Next Chief?; Venezuelan Crisis Worsens; Search For New Uber CEO; ExxonMobil2Q Results Mixed; Amazon Falls On Earnings; Overstock CEO On Amazon; Overstock CEO On Markets; `Cars By Overstock' Launch; Uber For Seniors; Awaiting GDP; 2Q GDP 1st Read; Speaker Ryan On Tax Reform; Starbucks Share Down Premarket; Starbucks Closing Teavana Stores; Starbucks To Buy China Joint Venture For $1.2 Billion; Tesla Delivers 30 Model 3s; Amazon 2Q Earnings Mixed; Uber For Seniors; Common Courtesy Is A Car Sharing Ride For Senior CitizensMaria Bartiromo, Kirsten Haglund, Dagen McDowell, Kevin Kelly, Cheryl Casone, Jon Hilsenrath

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: -- for the country and our only regret tonight - our only regret is that we didn't achieve what we had hoped to accomplish.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Now republican leaders are looking ahead to tax reform and it is official the border-adjustment tax is now off the table. Paul Ryan told us last night, I sat down with the house speaker and he explained why he ended up compromising on the issue.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PAUL RYAN, SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: We looked at health care and said, let's make sure that we do tax reform better and differently. That is why the house who offered the border- adjustment tax realized that that was preventing us from getting consensus to get to tax reform and once we realized there is a perfectly viable way to tax reform without having to do that, we agreed to go that direction in the sake of consensus so we can get this done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More on why he says tax reform is critical to get to three percent growth to the economy. Meanwhile, drama in the west wing and I am not talking about the television show. Communications director Anthony Scaramucci making waves after scathing comments he made to a New Yorker magazine reporter, the fallouts coming up this morning. We're watching earnings from the oil joints today, ExxonMobiland Chevron reporting ahead of the opening bell this morning. The company is under pressure amid the recent decline in oil prices, ExxonMobildown 11 percent, chevron down nine percent. This is year-to-date.

Markets this morning under pressure today as well after a record-setting week. The Dow industrials set to open down about 20 points. NASDAQ down 30 points, down two-thirds of a percent. ExxonMobiljust reporting right now, revenue is above estimates, set $62.8 billion versus 61 billion, estimate in terms of the earnings -- that was a miss, in terms of earnings per share, so ExxonMobilhad been under some selling pressure, we'll see if that continues now with this breaking news.

We are waiting on GDP, we are getting our first look at the second quarter GDP, it's due out in 30 minutes, expectations call for growth of 2.6 percent for the second quarter and this of course is the first look at GDP. There will be revisions. In Europe, take a look at the indices this morning, the FT-100 is down two-thirds of a percent, the CAC Quarante is down better than one percent. And the DAX Index in Germany down almost half of a percent. In Asia overnight, markets were mostly lower as you see there.

Chaos in Venezuela reaching a fever pitch, the U.S. is ordering families of diplomats to leave immediately. Delta Airlines is also suspending flights to the country. The search for Uber's next CEO is narrowing. Meg Whitman took herself out of the running but it is a new edition that's taking many by surprise. We will tell you who that is, who Uber is looking for to fill that role.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, market strategist, Kevin Kelly, and political analyst, Kirsten Haglund. So happy you're here today. Good morning.

KIRTSEN HAGLUND, POLITICAL ANALYST: Oh, thank you. Crazy morning.

BARTIROMO: Happy Friday.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I know. Trying to can't keep up.

HAGLUND: TGIF, right?

MCDOWELL: Everything that's going on in just the last week. I can't keep up.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Drama in the White House, a failure last night in the senate. I don't know, so now Obamacare is the law of the land. What happens now, Dagen? It's just --

MCDOWELL: I suspect that if as Mitch McConnell seemed to indicate last night that if they even begin, the republicans working with democrats to shore up Obamacare, it's simply going to mean a lot more money, tens of billions of dollars, if not running into hundreds of billions of dollars to shore up these exchanges. Maybe you get rid of the medical devices tax but expect the M.D.'s investment taxes to stay in there which a lot of these republicans got behind. I don't - I --

BARTIROMO: This is what's been holding the economy back.

MCDOWELL: You're not going to a single player option which is what some democrats like the senator from Hawaii, Mazie Hironi - Hirono wants but you will - it would just be no entitlement reform, no reform of Medicaid and a lot more money.

KEVIN KELLY, MARKET STRATEGIST: It will just be big --

BARTIROMO: And this is what's been holding back the economy.

KELLY: Yes. It will be a big government central plan that will have no freedom of choice, there's no liberty in it, it's not going to contain cost. What it's going to do is it's going to hamper the system even more. It's going to continue to impact labor, that's why the labor participation rate, it's going to continue to impact small business, it's going to stifle this economy. It is a new around (INAUDIBLE) that's why it's just terrible.

BARTIROMO: All of this, because of this top story. The senate republicans health care bill failed last night. Three GOP lawmakers voted against the so-called skinny repeal bill including Arizona Senator John McCain, as well Senator Lisa Murkowski and Senator Susan Collins. Leaders from both parties spoke out after the vote. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R), KENTUCKY: Imagine many of our colleagues on the other side are celebrating. Probably pretty happy about all this. But the American people are hurting.

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D), NEW YORK: I would say to my dear friend the majority leader, we are not celebrating, we are relieved that millions and millions of people who would have been so drastically hurt by the three proposals put forward will at least retain their health care.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump tweeted his disappointment as well, here's what he said. Three republicans and 48 democrats let the American people down. As I said from the beginning, let Obamacare implode than deal. Watch. We are watching. Why couldn't republicans get their repeal passed, everybody has their own ideas and what this should look like. What really make me scratch my head and wonder if most of them all voted for a repeal and they've been talking about a repeal for seven years. And when they actually had the chance to do something, and fix things, they say no.

HAGLUND: You know what's really interesting was, it -- there was so much that happened yesterday, right? BARTIROMO: Move over millennials. One retired couple created a way to make ride-sharing more friendly for older citizens, senior citizens. It's catching Uber's attention as well. The nonprofit called "Common Courtesy" has a goal of extending Uber's convenience to seniors who don't have a smartphone or are not well-versed in using one. Joining us now are the cofounders of Common Courtesy, Bob and Anne Carr. Great to see you, guys. Thank you so much for joining us.

BOB CARR, COFOUNDER, COMMON COURTESY: Absolutely, good morning.

ANNE CARR, COFOUNDER, COMMON COURTESY: Good morning. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: How it works -- I think it's such a great idea for senior citizens. Is it sort of like an Access-A-Ride? I mean, that's really a bus that will handle several people, but this is one person in the car, right?

B. CARR: It -- of course, it's one person, with rideshare companies, but up to three people additionally can ride for the same fare, basically. So, we have some that are going to lunch, some that are individual or is more dignified, we believe.

A. CARR: Yes. And it's -- we call it "personal transportation" than --

B. CARR: Or as Anne calls it, micro-transportation.

A. CARR: Exactly.

B. CARR: So, it's a grading with mass transportation.

BARTIROMO: And it's such a good idea. It's a great idea.

KELLY: And how does it -- how does it work with Lyft and Uber and how does that whole process? So, if I'm an elderly person and trying to get a rideshare?

A. CARR: OK.

B. CARR: We basically see ourselves as we've engineered this, as an intermediary for both Uber and Lyft. We have systems that are both using a concierge or a dispatch from our office for those people who don't have a smartphone or don't want to use a smartphone, they can call a toll-free number. There are others who very professionally use their -- proficiently use their smartphone. So --

A. CARR: We have our riders register with us. And they get a specific rider I.D. number that tracks them. So, some of them can put this system into their app, on their phone, and use their smartphone, but others just don't feel comfortable doing that, so they call the toll-free number, and we schedule the ride for them. And then you can watch it on the screen to make sure that they link up. It's a beautiful system.

B. CARR: Yes. And it has been re-engineered over time.

MCDOWELL: Are you guys are not for profit?

A. CARR: Yes.

B. CARR: We are indeed. Yes. 10 years old.

MCDOWELL: Wow. 10 years old. How do you -- how do you fund yourselves?

B. CARR: Well, there are a number of different revenues. We hadn't had not enough, I guess, is the short answer to that. Anne has been asking that from the very beginning, but we've created a number of different revenue streams that would involve, like, a little bit more, a little bit of an upcharge for the ride, or there are a certain chapters that we have that also we've taught how to do this, so they might pay a fee. I guess our biggest dream and wish is for donations to come into the -- to the nonprofit to help us from the bootstrap stage.

BARTIROMO: What happens --

A. CARR: And also community.

BARTIROMO: What happened when Uber found out about your company?

B. CARR: Well, we started working with Uber when they first moved to Atlanta. And they were -- they were a little bit standoffish because this is not their wheelhouse. And yet, over time, they warmed up to the idea, and I really believe they love it. Now, both Uber and Lyft we love. And, you know, what -- the thing that we see is that we are trying to expand Uber and Lyft's markets from -- get this from overserved to the underserved.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So, you're operating -- you're operating where right now and where do you hope to operate?

B. CARR: Well, throughout the U.S., we see no reason why it shouldn't expand throughout the U.S. Right now, we're -- we have chapters in -- several in Atlanta, and in Virginia Beach, Wichita, Kansas.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic. Great idea, Bob and Anne. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. We'll be watching.

A. CARR: Well, thank you.

B. CARR: Thanks for having -- OK.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Bye Ann and Bob Carr.

B. CARR: Stay tuned. OK.

BARTIROMO: The co-founders of Common Courtesy. We'll take a break and then we've got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: I love my emoji. Let's get some final thoughts from this all- star panel. Kirsten Haglund.

HAGLUND: I can't wait to see week two with our new Communications Director. He better stay on message. And also happy anniversary to my hubby of five years.

BARTIROMO: Hey, happy anniversary. Kevin Kelly?

KELLY: The five-year anniversary is the wedding anniversary. Who would have (INAUDIBLE) it, Amazon, this is a buying opportunity. So, I don't know why you don't do it.

BARTIROMO: You would be buying it then?

KELLY: Yes, absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Jon Hilsenrath said these low long-term interest rates maybe signal another bubble if they stay in place. My prediction is it's an entitlement bubble. The Republicans can't even reform expanded Medicaid. We are in store for a debt crisis in this country.

BARTIROMO: Not good. Thanks for being with us. Have a great weekend, everybody. I'll see you on "WALL STREET WEEK" and "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES". "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Here's Stuart.

urn:contentItem:5KRW-JXN1-DY0W-44C3-00000-00Obamacare Website Woes; No More Overdrafts?; Double Compensation for Government Employee for Shutdown Period; Dangerous Prisoners Escape from2013-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisObamacare Website Woes; No More Overdrafts?; Double Compensation for Government Employee for Shutdown Period; Dangerous Prisoners Escape fromLanhamFULL TEXT

GERRI WILLIS, HOST, "THE WILLIS REPORT": Hello, everybody. I'm Gerri Willis. Tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): The list of technical problems with ObamaCare growth. No, there's trouble when even the big health insurers start to complain. Also, no more overdraft fees. The banks are being generous. They just might start refusing consumers an overdraft. And federal workers double- dipping because it was shutdown. Is that legal? We are on the case tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

It has been nearly three weeks since the ObamaCare exchanges opened, and the backlash is growing. You know, now is not just consumers complaining that they can't get on, they can't get logged in and enroll. It's insurers, the private sector who presumably would benefit from this law, they say the system is not working. Now, the latest problem insurance companies getting bad information from the ObamaCare exchanges themselves.

With us now United Health Group board member Gail Wilensky, she is the former Medicare director under President George H. W. Bush. John Engates, the CTO of Rackspace. And Paul Howard, the senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

Paul, let me start with you. So, what are these insurers complaining about? What's going around for them? It seems that this should all benefit them.

PAUL HOWARD, MANHATTAN INSTITUTE: Now, the files from e-commerce (ph) are coming to them and they're saying, there is missing misinformation, there's duplicate information, there's corrupt information, such that they have to go back to the enrollees manually and say, is this information correct. If you just have a few thousand applications like we do today, that is fine. If you have millions, that is a disaster.

WILLIS: I am hearing that the system is enrolling spouses as children. I mean, it is crazy the kinds of mistakes going on. John, to you, what happened here? I'm used to being online all the time. I don't have problems like this ever.

JOHN ENGATES, RACKSPACE CHIEF TECHNOLOGY OFFICER: Right. Well, this is a brand new system, it's relatively untested system. It was built over the last probably six months or so and put together, you know, from you know, sort of a rapid fire set of requirements. And I think what you are seeing is just the lack of, you know, testing and maturity of the platform that powers this website. This, you know, it's more or less like an e- commerce website.

WILLIS: Yes.

ENGATES: Like you said, your online all the time. And it should be that same kind of experience.

WILLIS: Well, I have to tell you, mature, young, old, it ain't working.

ENGATES: That's right.

WILLIS: And it is shocking to me the degree that we're having problems, the big numbers that we heard this week, one person of people who visited this website were actually able to enroll. Gail, you have called this whole thing a complete screw up, you have been an HHS, you've seen what goes on from the inside. Tell us your view on these headlines you're reading.

GAIL WILENSKY, UNITEDHEALTH GROUP BOARD MEMBER: I think what may have been a major contributing factor are two issues. One is that a lot of changes continued from CMS, the agency that is in charge of this for HHS to go to the contractors very late. And it meant that with the client putting change specs to the people putting this together, they didn't really have much of a change -- chance to test before it went online for the real. The reason I say that is some of the large vendors who are supporting the federalist exchanged are the same vendors you are providing support to the state exchanges that are working well.

So, it makes you think there is something about what is going on in those federal exchanges, and the instructions they were getting from the government about how they do it. I read a statistic today that was just amazing to me. This is from a Kaiser News reporter, normally a source, friendly to the administration.

WILLIS: That's right.

WILENSKY: It took him 17 days and 63 attempts in order to enroll. Clearly it's got to fix that, or people are going to go beyond frustration.

WILLIS: Wow, John, I just want to get you and what Gail saying here about what happened with the exchanges, the same company, that some of the same vendors used on the status changes as the federal exchange, that's just she just said. She says, there's something about the way the Fed did this, that screwed it up. What do you say? What do think? You're an expert on this.

ENGATES: Yes. So, this is a massive integration project that crossed a number of departments probably spread out in many states and many federal agencies. And that is a big job, that's a big task. And you have to have expertise in doing that. And obviously, these government contractors do this kind of work, but maybe they did not have it experience that the scale, maybe they didn't have the time to do the legwork that they needed to do to pull together the agencies that are involved. I mean, if you imagine what is going on here, the system is looking up data in a variety of services and data bases all over the counter basically.

WILLIS: Well, that's true. It's bringing together a lot. But they had two in a half years to do it, Paul. And now we are hearing this company CGI, this is behind all of this, this is a Canadian company. It's not even an American company which I think is really funny. There are big time government contractor. The government has been better going with the same guys to develop Google or Amazon or Twitter or Facebook.

HOWARD: Right. So, the government procurement rules actually favor people have done business with the government before, have large lobby arms in Congress. Obviously, if you went with somebody like Google or Adele, you would be better off at this point. CMS also made a critical decision that it was going to be the quarterback for all the private contractors instead of contracting that decision now to somebody who was experience that kind of integration. CMS is not known of its IT healthcare expertise, so that was probably also a critical problem.

WILLIS: Well, there is a lot going on here Gail. You were involved with the Medicare prescription drug program, the roll out of that. And I remember it was originally criticized for being too complicated. That was the media's problem with it. Did it go better than ObamaCare is?

WILENSKY: It certainly did not have these kinds of problems. Every new program has some start up problems. Everyone knew October 1st was going to be a bit rocky and bumpy, as January 1st will be for sure. I do not think anyone anticipated that kind of problems that we're seeing to multiple attempts, people who go part way through, get an error message and get thrown off. This is beyond any expectations that I have heard about. The administration has until the middle of November to get all of these problems reasonably fixed or there's going to be great difficulty in having an effective January 1st.

WILLIS: You know, they're setting up a situation where people are going to break the law because they don't have a way of getting signed on legally. I think that's one of the major stories is not being reported right now, Paul. What do you say to this inability to get this thing together and now we're starting to hear some insurers might actually start their own private exchange because they cannot get anything done with the Obamacare network.

HOWARD: Right. It is a real problem for the insurers, if the only people who get through this process and get enrolled are desperate and sick. That creates a bad health risk for insurers --

WILLIS: But it's not just those people. It's everybody. Nobody can get signed on. One percent of the people, one percent of the people who went on this site could actually enroll.

HOWARD: Right. But that young healthy person might give up after the first time. A desperate sick person might go 50 or 60 times to get through. Health insurers are concerned they're going to be left holding the bag.

WILLIS: Hey, John, if you were designing a site and have the kinds of situations, reactions that this exchange is having, would you keep that job or would they replace you with somebody else?

ENGATES: We would be fired. We would be fired for sure. As a service provider you have to deliver and you've got to do these kinds of things, you know, sort of for the maximum up time and the performance of the site. And, you know, this one is not performing and I think you probably get fired.

WILLIS: I want everybody to jump in on this. But Gail, I start with you. Congressman Tim Huelskamp said this week, he said, this is so problematic, this rollout that we should delay the individual mandate for a year not only that, not only should we, but he predicted the president would. What do you make of that?

WILENSKY: Well, this issue has been raised as soon as the president of administration pushed back the employer mandate for a year. Why should we have employers getting an extra year, but insist that individuals must have insurance or pay a penalty.

WILLIS: Right.

WILENSKY: I think the congressman is raising a very important point that if this problem does not get fixed quickly it is going to be very difficult to hold people accountable for not having insurance penalizing them if they don't when they have a reasonable response of saying, I tried. You've made it so difficult, I could not do it. So, I said, I think there is window may be up to a month, if it is not solved, there's going to be a lot of bipartisan pressure to start in this direction of saying, we need more time, we need more enrollment, we need more time before people are penalized. So, I would not be surprised if this happens.

WILLIS: Paul, do you think the president will back off?

HOWARD: If you'd ask me, two and a half weeks, there was no way, it's unthinkable the president would do that. But if this trend continues, and he's going to get an earful from the insurance companies, from the community backers like even the Robert Gibbs as reclined of the Washington Post have said, look, this is a failure right now. They do have to get things cleaned up very quickly. Things which were once unthinkable become thinkable.

WILLIS: John, how long would it take you to fix this thing if you were in charge?

ENGATES: I think we could do it in few weeks.

WILLIS: What's that?

ENGATES: I think we could do it in a couple of weeks.

WILLIS: Really?

ENGATES: Honestly, I think that it could be done. Yes. I mean, well, it depends on where the problem is honestly. I think that one of the things I would do immediately is start to simplify the site to make it easier for customers, our users to at least compare and understand what is going on. And then I would re-architect certain portions of the side to go faster and be more streamlined.

WILLIS: Faster, streamlined. That is what we expect out of an online site. Gail, John and Paul, thanks for coming on tonight.

ENGATES: Sure.

WILLIS: Great conversation. Really interesting. So, we've got about three weeks to get this thing fixed. Thanks a bunch.

HOWARD: Thank you.

WILENSKY: Thanks.

WILLIS: Thank you so much. Now we want to know what you think. Here is our question tonight. Do you think President Obama will delay the individual mandate? Log on to Gerriwillis.com, vote on the right-hand side of the screen, I will show you the results of the end of tonight's show.

And, you know what, we have gotten so much response from you about your concerns and questions about ObamaCare that we will do another call-in show this Monday. Look, we know you are squeezed. It's you against ObamaCare, you against the IRS, you against the big companies that want to loot your bank account with fees. We get it. We're here to help. So, start e-mailing and tweeting us with your ObamaCare questions. On Monday, there's going to be a toll-free number like we usually do.

You can call in during the show, ask me and a panel of experts. We get some great experts. Ask these questions directly or even just make a comment. OK, we've got more to come this hour including the latest on new study that shows sleeping may help prevent Alzheimer's.

And next, one of the biggest banks in the U.S. is trying to get the consumer on its side. We will look at a plan by Bank of America to save you money on fees.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: Big news in banking. You may soon have to say goodbye to spending more than you have protection. Remember that? Bank of America is considering a new checking account that prohibits overdrafts but protects you from those $35 fees that can add up.

Joining us now, Robin Sidel, a reporter with the Wall Street Journal. Robin, great to have you here.

ROBIN SIDEL, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL REPORTER: Thank you.

WILLIS: What is Bank of America talking about? Keep in mind, they are not saying that they're doing this. This is all behind closed doors.

SIDEL: Right. I mean, they have been spending the past year trying to figure out how to overhaul their checking accounts. A lot of other banks have already done so. And one of the things they're considering is giving people the choice to not have overdraft, it won't be, you could still choose between a couple of different checking accounts. But one of the accounts would not let you.

WILLIS: So, this is great. Because at the end of the day, what these banks were typically doing is you have to opt out of what they called overdraft protection. But nobody ever saw the disclosure. Nobody ever took advantage of it. You're out with your debit card and you're shopping, and all of a sudden, you don't realize that you're charging for something you don't have in your bank account.

SIDEL: Right.

WILLIS: A lot of people have been in that situation, and 35 bucks a hit is a lot of money.

SIDEL: Uh-hm. And consumer advocates and lawmakers and regulators just really have slammed the industry, for disclosure, for lack of transparency, and for the high level of fees. So, they are addressing that here.

WILLIS: I have to, you know, full confession here, I gave Bank of America a very hard time whenever talking about introducing debit card fees. I cut off my Bank of America card on air. If they do this, I'm going to have to do something really positive because I think that is great. Why allow people to run up those fees when they do not even know that they're doing it in many cases?

SIDEL: Right. I mean, some people actually, it is interesting. They're trying to start the line. Some people actually like having that protection and are willing to pay the $35 fee to buy or do whatever they want.

WILLIS: But if that is the case, have them opt in, don't have me have to decide to opt out of some named program that I don't even understand. Now, you say this might be part of a bigger program to redefine checking.

SIDEL: Yes.

WILLIS: What is going on there?

SIDEL: Well, they have been testing for the past year in Massachusetts, Arizona, Georgia, a bunch of different pilot tests for checking accounts. And they're trying to figure out what to do. And they are also pretty sensitive to public criticism since the debit card fiasco from a couple of years ago. They are sensitive to that.

WILLIS: They are nervous.

SIDEL: Yes, of course they are.

WILLIS: They don't know what's going to happen.

SIDEL: Of course they are.

WILLIS: So, what could we see ultimately do you think?

SIDEL: Well, I think you will probably see a couple of checking accounts. I think there's probably going to be a checking account geared to the low end, to people who do not carry a lot of a high balance, who don't have other relationships with the bank like a mortgage or credit card. I mean, that is kind of the way banks are going. Some banks are trying to, you know, push of those customers. They do not want them because checking accounts are actually expensive for the bank to maintain.

WILLIS: How much does it cost the bank to have a checking account?

SIDEL: It can cost the bank a few hundred bucks a year to maintain a checking account, and if you don't keep a lot of money in the bank and if you don't have other relationships with the bank and they're not getting any fees from you, that is the cost for them.

WILLIS: What do you take is the ultimate implications of what banks are doing? Because they are saying, we want those really wealthy customers that could get mortgages from us, they invest with us, they have all kinds of accounts with us. But the other people, we want to get rid of them. What would be the impact of that long-term?

SIDEL: Well, I think you will going to just see different kinds of accounts for different kinds of people. Chase for example is pushing a prepaid card called liquid that they are gearing towards the lower end. There is no ability to overdraft on it either. So, they're just trying to manage their losses, but as well as still keep revenue from people who are willing to pay.

WILLIS: You know, these prepaid cards, I got to tell you, they often have big fees with them. And I have not been a fan for that very reason.

SIDEL: They are changing, and the prepaid cards that are being introduced now from the banks are actually a lot lower than the ones that you used to be able to just buy at the drugstore or something. So, because -- they've got really slammed for those as well.

WILLIS: So, you think it's better for people to have a real relationship with the bank other than just buying some card that they can then use in any ATM? I mean, at the end of the day, don't you want to build a relationship that then leads to, you know, OK now we will going to get the mortgage, maybe we get to the bank that we have our checking account with, now we're going to get the loans for college. Maybe we will go to them too. You know, the world has changed, but I hate to think that people are so disconnected from the financial system that they have no relationship.

SIDEL: Well, they are. There are plenty of people who are, and there are also people who don't want to put all their eggs in one basket, who don't want to have a complete relationship with the bank. You know, there are plenty of people who don't like truck banks, don't trust them, are afraid of them.

WILLIS: It's a lot of people. I have to tell you, the banks brought that on themselves in many ways with some of their policies. And of course, you know, the great recession did not do a lot to help that or the bailouts.

SIDEL: Right. And so, they are very aware of all that.

WILLIS: Robin, thanks for coming on. Very good to see you. Great story. We will continue to watch this. It's going to be interesting.

SIDEL: Sure will. Thanks.

WILLIS: Thank you.

Later in the show, how the government shutdown is actually costing the government more than if it stayed open. And next, we answer the question how you do that. We'll tell you the best way to get a good night's sleep and the real reason why it is so important. Look at Bunny sleeping. Bunny. Wake up, Bunny. We are doing the show. Come on, Bunny.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
