urn:contentItem:59MY-TW21-F190-V4R4-00000-00Obamacare Website Woes; No More Overdrafts?; Double Compensation for Government Employee for Shutdown Period; Dangerous Prisoners Escape from2013-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisObamacare Website Woes; No More Overdrafts?; Double Compensation for Government Employee for Shutdown Period; Dangerous Prisoners Escape from

GERRI WILLIS, HOST, "THE WILLIS REPORT": Hello, everybody. I'm Gerri Willis. Tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): The list of technical problems with ObamaCare growth. No, there's trouble when even the big health insurers start to complain. Also, no more overdraft fees. The banks are being generous. They just might start refusing consumers an overdraft. And federal workers double- dipping because it was shutdown. Is that legal? We are on the case tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

It has been nearly three weeks since the ObamaCare exchanges opened, and the backlash is growing. You know, now is not just consumers complaining that they can't get on, they can't get logged in and enroll. It's insurers, the private sector who presumably would benefit from this law, they say the system is not working. Now, the latest problem insurance companies getting bad information from the ObamaCare exchanges themselves.

With us now United Health Group board member Gail Wilensky, she is the former Medicare director under President George H. W. Bush. John Engates, the CTO of Rackspace. And Paul Howard, the senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

Paul, let me start with you. So, what are these insurers complaining about? What's going around for them? It seems that this should all benefit them.

PAUL HOWARD, MANHATTAN INSTITUTE: Now, the files from e-commerce (ph) are coming to them and they're saying, there is missing misinformation, there's duplicate information, there's corrupt information, such that they have to go back to the enrollees manually and say, is this information correct. If you just have a few thousand applications like we do today, that is fine. If you have millions, that is a disaster.

WILLIS: I am hearing that the system is enrolling spouses as children. I mean, it is crazy the kinds of mistakes going on. John, to you, what happened here? I'm used to being online all the time. I don't have problems like this ever.

JOHN ENGATES, RACKSPACE CHIEF TECHNOLOGY OFFICER: Right. Well, this is a brand new system, it's relatively untested system. It was built over the last probably six months or so and put together, you know, from you know, sort of a rapid fire set of requirements. And I think what you are seeing is just the lack of, you know, testing and maturity of the platform that powers this website. This, you know, it's more or less like an e- commerce website.

WILLIS: Yes.

ENGATES: Like you said, your online all the time. And it should be that same kind of experience.

WILLIS: Well, I have to tell you, mature, young, old, it ain't working.

ENGATES: That's right.

WILLIS: And it is shocking to me the degree that we're having problems, the big numbers that we heard this week, one person of people who visited this website were actually able to enroll. Gail, you have called this whole thing a complete screw up, you have been an HHS, you've seen what goes on from the inside. Tell us your view on these headlines you're reading.

GAIL WILENSKY, UNITEDHEALTH GROUP BOARD MEMBER: I think what may have been a major contributing factor are two issues. One is that a lot of changes continued from CMS, the agency that is in charge of this for HHS to go to the contractors very late. And it meant that with the client putting change specs to the people putting this together, they didn't really have much of a change -- chance to test before it went online for the real. The reason I say that is some of the large vendors who are supporting the federalist exchanged are the same vendors you are providing support to the state exchanges that are working well.

So, it makes you think there is something about what is going on in those federal exchanges, and the instructions they were getting from the government about how they do it. I read a statistic today that was just amazing to me. This is from a Kaiser News reporter, normally a source, friendly to the administration.

WILLIS: That's right.

WILENSKY: It took him 17 days and 63 attempts in order to enroll. Clearly it's got to fix that, or people are going to go beyond frustration.

WILLIS: Wow, John, I just want to get you and what Gail saying here about what happened with the exchanges, the same company, that some of the same vendors used on the status changes as the federal exchange, that's just she just said. She says, there's something about the way the Fed did this, that screwed it up. What do you say? What do think? You're an expert on this.

ENGATES: Yes. So, this is a massive integration project that crossed a number of departments probably spread out in many states and many federal agencies. And that is a big job, that's a big task. And you have to have expertise in doing that. And obviously, these government contractors do this kind of work, but maybe they did not have it experience that the scale, maybe they didn't have the time to do the legwork that they needed to do to pull together the agencies that are involved. I mean, if you imagine what is going on here, the system is looking up data in a variety of services and data bases all over the counter basically.

WILLIS: Well, that's true. It's bringing together a lot. But they had two in a half years to do it, Paul. And now we are hearing this company CGI, this is behind all of this, this is a Canadian company. It's not even an American company which I think is really funny. There are big time government contractor. The government has been better going with the same guys to develop Google or Amazon or Twitter or Facebook.

HOWARD: Right. So, the government procurement rules actually favor people have done business with the government before, have large lobby arms in Congress. Obviously, if you went with somebody like Google or Adele, you would be better off at this point. CMS also made a critical decision that it was going to be the quarterback for all the private contractors instead of contracting that decision now to somebody who was experience that kind of integration. CMS is not known of its IT healthcare expertise, so that was probably also a critical problem.

WILLIS: Well, there is a lot going on here Gail. You were involved with the Medicare prescription drug program, the roll out of that. And I remember it was originally criticized for being too complicated. That was the media's problem with it. Did it go better than ObamaCare is?

WILENSKY: It certainly did not have these kinds of problems. Every new program has some start up problems. Everyone knew October 1st was going to be a bit rocky and bumpy, as January 1st will be for sure. I do not think anyone anticipated that kind of problems that we're seeing to multiple attempts, people who go part way through, get an error message and get thrown off. This is beyond any expectations that I have heard about. The administration has until the middle of November to get all of these problems reasonably fixed or there's going to be great difficulty in having an effective January 1st.

WILLIS: You know, they're setting up a situation where people are going to break the law because they don't have a way of getting signed on legally. I think that's one of the major stories is not being reported right now, Paul. What do you say to this inability to get this thing together and now we're starting to hear some insurers might actually start their own private exchange because they cannot get anything done with the Obamacare network.

HOWARD: Right. It is a real problem for the insurers, if the only people who get through this process and get enrolled are desperate and sick. That creates a bad health risk for insurers --

WILLIS: But it's not just those people. It's everybody. Nobody can get signed on. One percent of the people, one percent of the people who went on this site could actually enroll.

HOWARD: Right. But that young healthy person might give up after the first time. A desperate sick person might go 50 or 60 times to get through. Health insurers are concerned they're going to be left holding the bag.

WILLIS: Hey, John, if you were designing a site and have the kinds of situations, reactions that this exchange is having, would you keep that job or would they replace you with somebody else?

ENGATES: We would be fired. We would be fired for sure. As a service provider you have to deliver and you've got to do these kinds of things, you know, sort of for the maximum up time and the performance of the site. And, you know, this one is not performing and I think you probably get fired.

WILLIS: I want everybody to jump in on this. But Gail, I start with you. Congressman Tim Huelskamp said this week, he said, this is so problematic, this rollout that we should delay the individual mandate for a year not only that, not only should we, but he predicted the president would. What do you make of that?

WILENSKY: Well, this issue has been raised as soon as the president of administration pushed back the employer mandate for a year. Why should we have employers getting an extra year, but insist that individuals must have insurance or pay a penalty.

WILLIS: Right.

WILENSKY: I think the congressman is raising a very important point that if this problem does not get fixed quickly it is going to be very difficult to hold people accountable for not having insurance penalizing them if they don't when they have a reasonable response of saying, I tried. You've made it so difficult, I could not do it. So, I said, I think there is window may be up to a month, if it is not solved, there's going to be a lot of bipartisan pressure to start in this direction of saying, we need more time, we need more enrollment, we need more time before people are penalized. So, I would not be surprised if this happens.

WILLIS: Paul, do you think the president will back off?

HOWARD: If you'd ask me, two and a half weeks, there was no way, it's unthinkable the president would do that. But if this trend continues, and he's going to get an earful from the insurance companies, from the community backers like even the Robert Gibbs as reclined of the Washington Post have said, look, this is a failure right now. They do have to get things cleaned up very quickly. Things which were once unthinkable become thinkable.

WILLIS: John, how long would it take you to fix this thing if you were in charge?

ENGATES: I think we could do it in few weeks.

WILLIS: What's that?

ENGATES: I think we could do it in a couple of weeks.

WILLIS: Really?

ENGATES: Honestly, I think that it could be done. Yes. I mean, well, it depends on where the problem is honestly. I think that one of the things I would do immediately is start to simplify the site to make it easier for customers, our users to at least compare and understand what is going on. And then I would re-architect certain portions of the side to go faster and be more streamlined.

WILLIS: Faster, streamlined. That is what we expect out of an online site. Gail, John and Paul, thanks for coming on tonight.

ENGATES: Sure.

WILLIS: Great conversation. Really interesting. So, we've got about three weeks to get this thing fixed. Thanks a bunch.

HOWARD: Thank you.

WILENSKY: Thanks.

WILLIS: Thank you so much. Now we want to know what you think. Here is our question tonight. Do you think President Obama will delay the individual mandate? Log on to Gerriwillis.com, vote on the right-hand side of the screen, I will show you the results of the end of tonight's show.

And, you know what, we have gotten so much response from you about your concerns and questions about ObamaCare that we will do another call-in show this Monday. Look, we know you are squeezed. It's you against ObamaCare, you against the IRS, you against the big companies that want to loot your bank account with fees. We get it. We're here to help. So, start e-mailing and tweeting us with your ObamaCare questions. On Monday, there's going to be a toll-free number like we usually do.

You can call in during the show, ask me and a panel of experts. We get some great experts. Ask these questions directly or even just make a comment. OK, we've got more to come this hour including the latest on new study that shows sleeping may help prevent Alzheimer's.

And next, one of the biggest banks in the U.S. is trying to get the consumer on its side. We will look at a plan by Bank of America to save you money on fees.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: Big news in banking. You may soon have to say goodbye to spending more than you have protection. Remember that? Bank of America is considering a new checking account that prohibits overdrafts but protects you from those $35 fees that can add up.

Joining us now, Robin Sidel, a reporter with the Wall Street Journal. Robin, great to have you here.

ROBIN SIDEL, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL REPORTER: Thank you.

WILLIS: What is Bank of America talking about? Keep in mind, they are not saying that they're doing this. This is all behind closed doors.

SIDEL: Right. I mean, they have been spending the past year trying to figure out how to overhaul their checking accounts. A lot of other banks have already done so. And one of the things they're considering is giving people the choice to not have overdraft, it won't be, you could still choose between a couple of different checking accounts. But one of the accounts would not let you.

WILLIS: So, this is great. Because at the end of the day, what these banks were typically doing is you have to opt out of what they called overdraft protection. But nobody ever saw the disclosure. Nobody ever took advantage of it. You're out with your debit card and you're shopping, and all of a sudden, you don't realize that you're charging for something you don't have in your bank account.

SIDEL: Right.

WILLIS: A lot of people have been in that situation, and 35 bucks a hit is a lot of money.

SIDEL: Uh-hm. And consumer advocates and lawmakers and regulators just really have slammed the industry, for disclosure, for lack of transparency, and for the high level of fees. So, they are addressing that here.

WILLIS: I have to, you know, full confession here, I gave Bank of America a very hard time whenever talking about introducing debit card fees. I cut off my Bank of America card on air. If they do this, I'm going to have to do something really positive because I think that is great. Why allow people to run up those fees when they do not even know that they're doing it in many cases?

SIDEL: Right. I mean, some people actually, it is interesting. They're trying to start the line. Some people actually like having that protection and are willing to pay the $35 fee to buy or do whatever they want.

WILLIS: But if that is the case, have them opt in, don't have me have to decide to opt out of some named program that I don't even understand. Now, you say this might be part of a bigger program to redefine checking.

SIDEL: Yes.

WILLIS: What is going on there?

SIDEL: Well, they have been testing for the past year in Massachusetts, Arizona, Georgia, a bunch of different pilot tests for checking accounts. And they're trying to figure out what to do. And they are also pretty sensitive to public criticism since the debit card fiasco from a couple of years ago. They are sensitive to that.

WILLIS: They are nervous.

SIDEL: Yes, of course they are.

WILLIS: They don't know what's going to happen.

SIDEL: Of course they are.

WILLIS: So, what could we see ultimately do you think?

SIDEL: Well, I think you will probably see a couple of checking accounts. I think there's probably going to be a checking account geared to the low end, to people who do not carry a lot of a high balance, who don't have other relationships with the bank like a mortgage or credit card. I mean, that is kind of the way banks are going. Some banks are trying to, you know, push of those customers. They do not want them because checking accounts are actually expensive for the bank to maintain.

WILLIS: How much does it cost the bank to have a checking account?

SIDEL: It can cost the bank a few hundred bucks a year to maintain a checking account, and if you don't keep a lot of money in the bank and if you don't have other relationships with the bank and they're not getting any fees from you, that is the cost for them.

WILLIS: What do you take is the ultimate implications of what banks are doing? Because they are saying, we want those really wealthy customers that could get mortgages from us, they invest with us, they have all kinds of accounts with us. But the other people, we want to get rid of them. What would be the impact of that long-term?

SIDEL: Well, I think you will going to just see different kinds of accounts for different kinds of people. Chase for example is pushing a prepaid card called liquid that they are gearing towards the lower end. There is no ability to overdraft on it either. So, they're just trying to manage their losses, but as well as still keep revenue from people who are willing to pay.

WILLIS: You know, these prepaid cards, I got to tell you, they often have big fees with them. And I have not been a fan for that very reason.

SIDEL: They are changing, and the prepaid cards that are being introduced now from the banks are actually a lot lower than the ones that you used to be able to just buy at the drugstore or something. So, because -- they've got really slammed for those as well.

WILLIS: So, you think it's better for people to have a real relationship with the bank other than just buying some card that they can then use in any ATM? I mean, at the end of the day, don't you want to build a relationship that then leads to, you know, OK now we will going to get the mortgage, maybe we get to the bank that we have our checking account with, now we're going to get the loans for college. Maybe we will go to them too. You know, the world has changed, but I hate to think that people are so disconnected from the financial system that they have no relationship.

SIDEL: Well, they are. There are plenty of people who are, and there are also people who don't want to put all their eggs in one basket, who don't want to have a complete relationship with the bank. You know, there are plenty of people who don't like truck banks, don't trust them, are afraid of them.

WILLIS: It's a lot of people. I have to tell you, the banks brought that on themselves in many ways with some of their policies. And of course, you know, the great recession did not do a lot to help that or the bailouts.

SIDEL: Right. And so, they are very aware of all that.

WILLIS: Robin, thanks for coming on. Very good to see you. Great story. We will continue to watch this. It's going to be interesting.

SIDEL: Sure will. Thanks.

WILLIS: Thank you.

Later in the show, how the government shutdown is actually costing the government more than if it stayed open. And next, we answer the question how you do that. We'll tell you the best way to get a good night's sleep and the real reason why it is so important. Look at Bunny sleeping. Bunny. Wake up, Bunny. We are doing the show. Come on, Bunny.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: All those sleepless nights are wreaking havoc on your brain. Scientists linking sleep deprivation to Alzheimer's and dementia. Stay with us.

WILLIS: A warning tonight, for sleep deprived, Americans, you could be more likely to developed Alzheimer's and dementia. I know it's disturbing, right? It's a revolutionary new study, Scientists have discovered that sleep detoxes your brain from harmful chemicals. So, how do you get enough shot eye to keep your mind and your body healthy?

Joining me now, Dr. Selene Parekh, orthopedic surgery professor at Duke University. Boy, that's a fancy pants title there. Dr. Selene, tell us this basic thing about sort of resetting your brain with sleep. How does that work?

DR. SELENE PAREKH, DUKE LAW ORTHOPEDIC SURGERY PROFESSOR: So, this was a very interesting study from the University of Rochester, and what we know is there are two basic cells in the brain. One is called a neuron which is the cell that's active when we're awake and working and doing things that we do during the day, the other is called the Glial Cell, and the Glial Cell supports the activity of the neuron. This study showed us that when we sleep, the neurons shrink. And by shrinking, the Glial Cells are able to pump fluid through the brain --

WILLIS: What fluid?

PAREKH: Cerebral spinal fluid which surrounds all of our brains, the Glial Cells can pumped in through the cells, and I should clear and detox your brain while you're sleeping at night.

WILLIS: So what are you getting rid of when you detox?

PAREKH: So, you're getting rid of toxic waste, toxic proteins, basically the garbage that the cells create through the day.

WILLIS: I'm taking a nap in a couple of minutes here.

(LAUGHTER)

OK, what kind of disorders could this new discovery treat?

PAREKH: So, interestingly, we know that disorders such as Alzheimer's, Parkinsons and other neurodegenerative diseases have a buildup of toxic material. So in theory, if you get sleep, you can detox the brain.

WILLIS: Right.

PAREKH: So potentially there might be a link here.

WILLIS: The other link you mentioned in the break that I was shocked at, you said some Alzheimer's is linked to depression. Tell us about that.

PAREKH: So there are some studies showing that elderly patients are more prone to depression, and some of those patients are more prone to having neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's. So we know that with depression you have sleep issues, with sleep issues potentially there's a link here with Alzheimer's.

WILLIS: You know, I'm listening to every word you're saying because my grandmother had Alzheimer's when she died, and I know it's in just about everybody's family. So, tell us how to get a good night sleep.

PAREKH: So the basic ways to get a good night sleep, number one, have a regular schedule so that you're sleeping normally, roughly at the same time every night, sleep in a temp rate type of room so not too hot, not too cold. Stay away from stimulant type of drinks and activities that are really going to get you hyper.

WILLIS: You don't take your iPad to bed with you, do you?

PAREKH: Try not to, and really limit your bedroom for sleep related activities. So, you don't want to take your iPad, you don't want to sit there and eat and do other things in the bedroom.

WILLIS: So, doctor, what about the length of time? Is it eight hours only or can you get away with six? Five? What do you say?

PAREKH: So, I think the research is still out, we all do recommend about eight hours of sleep, but some people get away with six, some people more. This study suggests that potentially sleeping more may be more beneficial for you.

WILLIS: So if I get up in the middle of the night and I'm wondering around the house because I can't sleep, what do can you recommend to people who have that problem of insomnia and want to get back to sleep and can't?

PAREKH: So, a couple of things, try some relaxation techniques whether it's relaxation music, relaxation scents, even yoga can actually help to relax your nerves and try to get you to sleep a little better.

WILLIS: All right. So far I have a nap on the list, I have yoga on the list. You've got a long list of things that a lack of sleep exacerbates including obesity, diabetes. How is this so important -- mood disorders, reproductive problems, the list goes on and on.

It does go on and on. So we know that during sleep your body repairs itself. So the bones, the tendons, the ligaments, the organs, your immune system, all of this repairs itself. I think this study is the tip of the iceberg trying to understand how sleep really affects our whole body.

WILLIS: Wow. Interesting stuff. Thanks for coming on and telling us about it.

PAREKH: Thanks.

WILLIS: I am going to take a long nap. So, all right, coming up, it's like a scene from a movie. Two murders walk out of prison in Florida, thanks to forged documents. Now the manhunt is on, we'll explain.

And next, the 16-day shutdown left thousands of workers furloughed, stuck at home with what they thought was no pay, but now they're not only getting back pay, they're double dipping. Our legal panel weighs in next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: A double paid vacation paid for you, by you, that it, the taxpayer. In case you needed another reason to be mad at the government, some federal workers furloughed during the government shutdown also got unemployment benefits despite receiving back pay. Hmm, is this legal? Do we have cause? Can we bring an action against the government? Joining me now, Bill Frumkin, attorney at Frumkin & Hunter. And Fox News legal analyst Lis Wiehl. All right, Lis, should these people get this money?

LIS WIEHL, FOX NEWS LEGAL ANALYST: No! Wait a second! OK, you get to go on vacation, you didn't want that vacation, I understand it. You should get the back pay, I understand that, from the feds, because you're a federal employee. But by the time you get this back pay you've already gone to the state, you've got unemployment, you have to give that back to the state. Because who else was paying for it, it was taxpayers, we're all paying for that's not right.

WILLIS: And, Bill, you have an argument against it?

BILL FRUMKIN, FRUMKIN & HUNTER ATTORNEY: Of course. Of course, I do. Let's pretend the two of you are working for a government-sponsored station, and they say to you ...

WIEHL: Analyze ...

FRUMKIN: You know what? We want you to now, you know, take unemployment, you are not going to be able to work, you have - bills aren't furloughed, you still have to pay your car, your rent, your mortgage, you this or your that, you don't know if you're going to get paid in the end, and you know what? We're going to pay you a month from now when your claim is ready to go. The point is that it's like a night differential, it's like overtime, working on the weekend, on a holiday. It's a problem, and a lot of people who weren't essential still worked even though they weren't getting paid just to keep things going.

WIEHL: But wait a second. OK. All right. So, let's take your premise as Gerri and I are working at this government-subsidized ...

WILLIS: We must be at NPR.

WIEHL: At NPR.

WILLIS: I'm Elmo. You're ...

WIEHL: I don't know - we're at NPR, considered, buy anyway, OK, so I take your premise at that point. You're right, people have to pay their bills, and what really upset me about the shutdown, one of the things was, it's always, you know, it's the secretaries and it's the people ...

FRUMKIN: Yes.

WIEHL: Not the high roll ...

FRUMKIN: That's correct.

WIEHL: I got that. But when they do get that shut back from - which says, here is your money that you would have received, so you could have paid, you know, all those bills could have been paid. Then, you can't double dip. Then you say, OK, those bills that you've got to give it back to the ...

WILLIS: Bill, you know, like, this makes a lot of sense. So now we're paying them twice ...

WIEHL: Right.

WILLIS: And you do realize, there's a one percent pay increase in that bill. They're going to get a pay increase on top of everything else.

FRUMKIN: OK, well, listen, this is true. But not everybody lives with, you know, a large bank account. People live check to check.

WILLIS: Right.

FRUMKIN: There's a lot of stress.

WILLIS: True.

FRUMKIN: There's a lot of issues.

WIEHL: But they're already getting the checks from the Fed, that's the point.

FRUMKIN: Yes, but the point is during that period of time, this uncertainty of which is quite uncertain and could happen again very quickly, they're living without not knowing whether they are going to be able to pay their bills.

WIEHL: But once that federal check -- that's what I'm saying, once that federal check comes in, which the feds have promised, right? Then the state should say, and by the way, most states -- Oregon is very unusual in this way -- that you must pay it back.

WILLIS: Let me tell you.

FRUMKIN: I don't disagree that it's unusual, but there is some method to the madness. How are those people going to pay their bills?

WIEHL: They've already paid them.

FRUMKIN: Not cash. They don't have more cash.

WILLIS: All right, hang on a second here, because there's an important number I want to get across to our viewers here. This is 43 million, that is the pay for furloughed workers. 77,000 of them receiving $43 million. So I still, I'm still mystified. So I get the unemployment money, right? And let me tell you, the government was out there telling people how to go about doing this. It wasn't like you had to figure it out on your own.

WIEHL: And that's OK.

WILLIS: Then we're trying to help you.

WIEHL: Right.

WILLIS: But now I get another check. I get a paid vacation. I get a paid - How is that fair?

WIEHL: Double paid vacation.

FRUMKIN: But it's not a paid vacation where you're going to the Bahamas and knowing that you're going to have a job when you come back, that you're going to be paid. It's somewhat like pain and suffering type money. Now, listen, I understand ...

WIEHL: Wait a second. Wait a second.

WILLIS: Oh!

WIEHL: You're putting on punitive damages here?

WILLIS: No. That's punitive damages, this is pain and suffering. But the point I'm making, this is really ...

WIEHL: You already have pain and suffering, don't worry about this ...

FRUMKIN: It's only Oregon that -- it's only Oregon that decided to do in this.

WIEHL: By the way, it's Oregon. You never say Oregon.

FRUMKIN: Well, you are not from Flushing. So I can't tell you.

(LAUGHTER)

WIEHL: Washington State.

FRUMKIN: But the point I want to make here is that there should be uniformity amongst all the states on this and there also should be ...

WILLIS: Uniformly they should pay the money back.

FRUMKIN: But there should be, I say, different - separate rules for people who are furloughed federal workers as opposed to private workers and state workers who apply for unemployment.

WIEHL: That's another - you just made my point again, thank you.

FRUMKIN: OK. How did I do that?

(LAUGHTER)

WIEHL: That - because it puts federal employees at a higher level than private employees or state employees. It puts them at a better - it put them at an advantage that private employees and state employees don't have. And by the way, we're talking numbers? For Oregon, just Oregon itself, $650,000 it's costing.

FRUMKIN: Yeah. But is this ...

WIEHL: That's a lot of money for a small state.

FRUMKIN: Is this - are you at an advantage, if there's a political fight that leaves you on the sidelines not knowing when you're going to be able to pay your bills...

WIEHL: But once you've got ...

FRUMKIN: That - I don't see ...

(CROSSTALK)

WILLIS: Wait, wait, wait, they knew this was coming. This had been a fight for two years. Two years ongoing.

WIEHL: Right.

WILLIS: What you do is you set aside a penny or a shekel every week to prepare.

FRUMKIN: Well, that - in a perfect world, you're absolutely right. But it is ...

(CROSSTALK)

FRUMKIN: I don't disagree, but ...

WIEHL: Or using the state money, because you don't know. You have that uncertainty.

WILLIS: Right. I'm not against it.

WIEHL: You take that state money. But once you do have the certainty of the fed money coming in ...

WILLIS: You give that back.

WIEHL: Give it back.

FRUMKIN: But you know what? There's an assumption there that people are making enough money to save money, and unfortunately even if they work for the government, that's not necessarily the case.

WILLIS: Well, look, I have nothing, I have no issue with taking unemployment if you're unemployed.

WIEHL: Right.

WILLIS: That's fine by me. But don't double dip, you know why? Because it's not coming out of the pocket of Dow chemical, it's not coming out of the pocket of Exxon, it's not coming out of the pocket of some big tech company. It's coming out of my pocket!

WIEHL: Right.

FRUMKIN: But remember, it's not like you're sitting on easy street while that's happening. It's just - you just ...

WILLIS: No, and I'm not sitting on easy street either.

WIEHL: (inaudible) sitting on easy street but the point is once you've gotten the money back, once you've been repaid for the time you didn't work, now you're back at your job, you give the money that the state gave you. That's just - this is fair ...

FRUMKIN: Well, I do understand that ...

WILLIS: I don't know how we're going to resolve this, guys.

FRUMKIN: I don't know that ...

WILLIS: Last word, though.

FRUMKIN: Listen, I gave you extra ...

(LAUGHTER)

FRUMKIN: I understand exactly what you say, it's a very difficult issue, but it's also not good to be people squeezed in a political fight. And that's ...

WILLIS: Amen.

(CROSSTALK)

WILLIS: ... squeezed in this political fight. And let me tell you, I couldn't agree with that more. That's the best thing you've said through the whole segment.

FRUMKIN: OK. Well, I had to say something that was good.

WILLIS: That was good. You're always good, Bill.

FRUMKIN: Oh, thank you.

WILLIS: Thank you, Lis. Great job.

FRUMKIN: Thank you. Thank you.

WILLIS: Tweet us, @gerriwillisfbn. We want to know what you think about that. And here comes top trending.

Time now for a look at the stories you're clicking on tonight on foxbusiness.com. The S&P 500 index rising further into record territory today, thanks to strong earnings from some of the biggest U.S. companies; General Electric and Morgan Stanley, all rose after reporting higher profits than analysts expected. As did Google, which sent shares of the tech giant up past the $1,000 mark for the first time. The stock had never before surpassed $928 a share in regular trading since going public nine years ago. Google says, well, advertising prices continue to decline, a larger number of people are now clicking on ads.

And commuters in San Francisco Bay Area are fuming mad over the second transit strike in four months. The walkout began after six months of on- again/off-again talks between Bay area rapid transit and its unions. The two sides can't reach an agreement on work rule issues. And the Fox Business Network is now live on Sirius XM radio. Yeah. And available to the radio network's 25 million subscribers. You can catch FBN -- this show too -- on Sirius XM channel 113. Welcome to all of you Sirius people out there.

And those are some of the hot stories right now on foxbusiness.com. When we come back, the story of Freddie the Frogcaster. We'll tell you all about it. And next, the manhunt is on for two convicted killers who escaped from a Florida prison using forged court documents. What is going on in the sunshine state?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: Talk about your get out of jail free card, in Florida two prisoners sentenced to life for murder, well, they somehow forged documents releasing them from prison. So now two very dangerous criminals are out and on the loose. How can this happen? Joining us now a Florida criminal defense attorney. Regina Sambanan. Regina, I can't say your last name. Sambanan (ph)...

REGINA TSOMBANAKIS, FLORIDA CRIMINAL ATTORNEY: Tsombanakis.

WILLIS: You're so good at that, thank you. Thanks for saving me on that one. I don't get how this happens more than once. It happens twice, not once, how could this possibly happen that they could forge these documents in prison?

TSOMBANAKIS: Well, they can't.

WILLIS: all right.

TSOMBANAKIS: Somebody's helping them. They don't have printers, they don't have Internet, and we're talking about two people that are not in jail for fraud, forgery or any type of crime like that, but for violent crimes, one of them not even smart enough to wear a ski mask. So, how are they doing it? They're not. Someone's got to be helping them. How do these papers go through? Someone's got to be paid to look the other way, someone's got to be paid to do this. It just doesn't make sense any other way.

WILLIS: Right. So somebody inside, that's what you're saying, right?

TSOMBANAKIS: It'd have to be, in my opinion.

WILLIS: Somebody inside the system that is getting these signatures and helping them getting this information out which means there's probably big bribes.

TSOMBANAKIS: Absolutely.

WILLIS: Right? Big bribes?

TSOMBANAKIS: And there's probably more than one person, absolutely, because there's probably someone producing the documents, somebody has to look the other way to process the documents. I mean it could be more than one person. But these two inmates are not sophisticated to figure out how to produce these documents, how to print these documents, how to get these documents into the right hands to be released.

WILLIS: So, is it possible that there are lots and lots of people just like them who are out and shouldn't be?

TSOMBANAKIS: It is possible. I don't think there's an abundance of it, but it is possible. These men just walked right out of jail. I mean, these are violent criminals. And one on September 26th, red flagged. How come the other one got out on October 8th? What's going on?

(LAUGHTER)

TSOMBANAKIS: What is going on at this prison, you know? I mean people just walk out? That should have been right there.

WILLIS: So, apparently, apparently there was an announcement this afternoon that they think these two guys or at least one of them is still in the state, which shocks me that they haven't left. But apparently ...

TSOMBANAKIS: It shouldn't shock you.

WILLIS: Do you think they'll catch up with them?

TSOMBANAKIS: Yeah. It shouldn't shock you, because they're in jail for a reason. Like I said, the guy didn't even wear a ski mask, OK? He's not forging documents. You know. Yes, he probably is still in the state. They probably are staying right here in this -- but the problem is there's victims. And they got to look over their shoulder - and they're worried. I mean you can't live in that kind of fear when the state's put the person away.

WILLIS: All right. Let me read the statement from the Florida Department of Corrections. Somebody's -- there's going to be a shoe to fall here - I don't know who is that going to be, but here's what they say for their part. "The department followed our procedures and protocols to the letter, so in this instance, the department didn't do anything wrong. And your response?

TSOMBANAKIS: How about the department passing the buck? Of course they did something wrong. Two people left the prison. How can you sit there and say you didn't do something wrong? Where are these people? How did you not know in this? I mean, please. It's time for government to get with it, get responsible. You let these people out, there's something going on in your prison, fix it. Don't sit there and go, oh, I don't know anything. Well who would then?

WILLIS: But who gets that ball rolling, Regina? I mean how does - what needs to happen next?

TSOMBANAKIS: From the top. From whoever's the warden, whoever's in charge of that prison.

WILLIS: How about the governor?

TSOMBANAKIS: The Department of Corrections.

WILLIS: How about the governor?

TSOMBANAKIS: Yeah, how about the governor? Exactly. Somebody's got to get involved. We're risking people's lives. They've killed before, they probably may kill again, and these victims don't deserve this. And we don't deserve this.

WILLIS: No, I certainly agree.

TSOMBANAKIS: What's the point, you know? If they can check in and out of the hotel?

WILLIS: Well put. Regina Tsombanakis, thank you for coming on. I think I said it right that time. I appreciate your time.

TSOMBANAKIS: Good.

WILLIS: Good job.

TSOMBANAKIS: Thank you.

WILLIS: Thank you. Well, still to come, Fox News meteorologist Janice Dean is here, but she's not telling us the weekend forecast. So, look at her new book. There she is right there. After the break. Freddy the Frogcaster. Well done.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: What does the frog have to do with forecasting? More than you might think what Freddy the Frog wants your kids to learn. Coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: All right, some kids say they want to be a police officer or a firefighter when they grow up, you know, you don't usually say meteorologist when you're a little kid, but one author's hoping to change all that. Fox News senior meteorologist Janice Dean is here to talk about her new children's book called "Freddy the Froggcaster." I love to say that, and why she feels it's so important kids learn about the weather from an early age. You've got to tell us about this book, it's so adorable.

JANICE DEAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR METEOROLOGIST: Thank you.

WILLIS: I've been able to page through it and look at it, it seems like a great read for kids.

DEAN: Did you learn something from it?

WILLIS: I learned something every single minute. Yes.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: I learned about cold fronts ...

DEAN: Yes.

WILLIS: Of thunderstorm clouds.

DEAN: Yep, I think it's important because I wanted to not only give kids an introduction to weather, but also help parents discuss why things happen in the atmosphere. I think sometimes as parents if I wasn't a meteorologist, I don't know if I would know what a cold front or a warm front or a low pressure/high pressure is, and I think I explain that well enough so that kids and parents can get involved in what's happening outside, and I think that's really important. I think kids at a young age have an appreciation for weather.

WILLIS: Oh, sure. And it's the only thing anybody ever talks about, so if you want your children to be part of the conversation ...

DEAN: Right.

WILLIS: They need to understand the weather.

DEAN: Absolutely. And like you mentioned, it opens up our dialogue with each other. I ride the elevator every day here at Fox, it's a nice day out here, Janice Dean, congratulations.

(LAUGHTER)

DEAN: Or is it going to rain on my parade tomorrow?

(LAUGHTER)

DEAN: So, you know, it brings us together as a community. I think as well if we see a bad storm go through our neighborhood, it also brings us together to help one another. Weather is always going to be a big part of our lives, and I think if we can get kids at an early age to start discovering it more, in the long term it's going to be good for everyone, and it might inspire a new generation of meteorologists.

WILLIS: Well, that's what I think is so interesting. Because one of the things you're saying tomorrow, I understand, in an op-ed editorial to be published is that it's all about math and science.

DEAN: Sure.

WILLIS: And this is a way to get kids interested in that. Tell us how numbers contribute to weather forecasting.

DEAN: Well, it's all about computer models. What we input into the computer models to tell us what the forecast is going to bring, numbers, temperatures, drop in pressure, barometer. Numbers are important when it comes to forecasting, and there's a lot of math, and there's is a lot of science. And we know as we get kids into schools these days if they're going to compete on the world stage, they have to know math, science, technology and engineering. So those two, math and science, that's what meteorology is all about. So if we can get them interested at a young age and think it's fun, maybe they will in turn think that math and science is fun when they go ...

WILLIS: Become an engineer, a meteorologist ...

DEAN: Absolutely.

WILLIS: Who knows? You know, the job openings, this is numbers from 2016, 16 percent of bachelor degrees will specialize in STEM, but the number of jobs that are open, one million. So we're not producing enough kids to actually do these jobs. Anything we can do to inspire them is a positive, right?

DEAN: Absolutely. Yeah, of course. And like I mentioned, when you have an appreciation for weather and you want to learn about it, you're going to learn about it in school, but it is a lot of math, it's a lot of science. I took something like -- that's called thermodynamics. It sounds scary, but it's fun when you can get all the numbers together. And they say this a lot, but weather is not an exact science. It won't be. We can't really predict that perfect forecast yet. But we'll certainly get them encouraged to really love those summits.

WILLIS: One final question, why a frog? How'd you come up with a frog?

DEAN: Well, the groundhog was taken.

(LAUGHTER)

DEAN: Right? And when I thought about it, I've always had a love of frogs. And, you know, Gerri, the interesting thing that I just learned about recently that, you know, gave me inspiration that Freddy was the right choice was that frogs, apparently, when a storm is coming they croak louder. How perfect is that?

WILLIS: They know. They know.

DEAN: Plus, I can also say things like frogcaster, the Frogs News Network, you know, it's cute names like Sally Croaker and Polly Woggins. I had a lot of fun. It's a lot of great names, it's the illustration, Russ Cox did all the illustrations, beautiful job, and at the back of the book there's some educational purpose too. There's a definition, a glossary of all the terms that I use on television.

WILLIS: Every single day.

DEAN: Yeah.

WILLIS: I have to tell you, it's a great book. Great reading.

DEAN: Thank you.

WILLIS: It's about at my level, now I think.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: Thanks for Janice, thanks for coming on.

DEAN: Anytime.

WILLIS: great job. Appreciate it. Well, if you can't get your hands on the Freddy the Frogcaster costume, and you're still looking for some Halloween ideas, tonight's top five might help. The most popular costumes of 2013, well, so far, number five is for those who want to go trick or twerking, Miley Cyrus. He MTV performance is leading to Teddy-bear inspired teddies. Mom and dad shouldn't see that. Number four, break out the camouflage so you can look like the cast of Duck Dynasty. Think beards and bandannas, you know, red neck chic. Number three is a fox. This is from a viral video, in the same (inaudible) as Gangnam style, it's an electronic dance song by a Norwegian artist. Number two, characters from "Breaking Bad." You can look like Walter White or Jesse Pinkman with a yellow hazmat suit that you can buy online for about 45 bucks apiece. And the number one most popular Halloween costume of 2013, the minions from "Despicable Me." I love that. You can dress up your child as a small, yellow, cylindrical creatures for about 35 bucks. Costumes for mom and dad, a little more expensive. Other looks on the list, characters from the "Game of Thrones" or the classic, Batman. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

WILLIS: The problems with Obamacare just don't stop. As insurers are now reporting the system is generating massive amounts of flawed data. Do you think these glitches will be enough to force the president to delay the individual mandate? Here is what some of you are posting on my Facebook page. Sandy says this, "I think the backlash will be so bad they will cancel it and transfer those folks in need to Medicaid. Interesting. And Maxine writes this, "No, because it would mean failure." That is possible, too. We also asked this question on Geriwillis.com. 20 percent of you said yes, 80 percent said no. "The president will not delay the mandate." And finally, you know, I cannot get over how bad Obamacare is. Look, I did not expect it to be successful, but I did not expect it a disaster either, and it has become just one more thing you have to figure out. The responsibility on your shoulders because the government sure is not helping you.

Look, I am getting tons of tweets, Facebook post, e-mails, all great questions and all deserving answers. So, we are stepping in again with another call-in show on Monday. Join us. I have a panel of experts, people who are not Obama-paid consultants to tell you the real deal on Obamacare. Look, we get it. You are squeezed. It is you against Obamacare, you against the IRS. You against the companies that see your wallet as their bottom line. So, we'll be there again. I hope you will join us Monday at 6:00 P.M. That is it for tonight's "WILLIS REPORT." Thanks for joining us. We will see you here Monday.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:59M9-JP31-JB20-G25X-00000-00Obamacare Website Woes; No More Overdrafts?; Double Compensation for Government Employee for Shutdown Period; Dangerous Prisoners Escape from Florida Jail; New Kids Book about Meteorology2013-10-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisTHE WILLIS REPORT6:00 PM ESTGail Wilensky, John Engates, Paul Howard, Selene Parekh, Lis Wiehl, Bill Frumkin, Regina Tsombanakis, Janice DeanNEWSBusiness101801cb.222Obamacare Website Woes; No More Overdrafts?; Double Compensation for Government Employee for Shutdown Period; Dangerous Prisoners Escape from Florida Jail; New Kids Book about MeteorologyGerri Willis

GERRI WILLIS, HOST, "THE WILLIS REPORT": Hello, everybody. I'm Gerri Willis. Tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

(voice-over): The list of technical problems with ObamaCare growth. No, there's trouble when even the big health insurers start to complain. Also, no more overdraft fees. The banks are being generous. They just might start refusing consumers an overdraft. And federal workers double- dipping because it was shutdown. Is that legal? We are on the case tonight on THE WILLIS REPORT.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

It has been nearly three weeks since the ObamaCare exchanges opened, and the backlash is growing. You know, now is not just consumers complaining that they can't get on, they can't get logged in and enroll. It's insurers, the private sector who presumably would benefit from this law, they say the system is not working. Now, the latest problem insurance companies getting bad information from the ObamaCare exchanges themselves.

With us now United Health Group board member Gail Wilensky, she is the former Medicare director under President George H. W. Bush. John Engates, the CTO of Rackspace. And Paul Howard, the senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

Paul, let me start with you. So, what are these insurers complaining about? What's going around for them? It seems that this should all benefit them.

PAUL HOWARD, MANHATTAN INSTITUTE: Now, the files from e-commerce (ph) are coming to them and they're saying, there is missing misinformation, there's duplicate information, there's corrupt information, such that they have to go back to the enrollees manually and say, is this information correct. If you just have a few thousand applications like we do today, that is fine. If you have millions, that is a disaster.

WILLIS: I am hearing that the system is enrolling spouses as children. I mean, it is crazy the kinds of mistakes going on. John, to you, what happened here? I'm used to being online all the time. I don't have problems like this ever.

JOHN ENGATES, RACKSPACE CHIEF TECHNOLOGY OFFICER: Right. Well, this is a brand new system, it's relatively untested system. It was built over the last probably six months or so and put together, you know, from you know, sort of a rapid fire set of requirements. And I think what you are seeing is just the lack of, you know, testing and maturity of the platform that powers this website. This, you know, it's more or less like an e- commerce website.

WILLIS: Yes.

ENGATES: Like you said, your online all the time. And it should be that same kind of experience.

WILLIS: Well, I have to tell you, mature, young, old, it ain't working.

ENGATES: That's right.

WILLIS: And it is shocking to me the degree that we're having problems, the big numbers that we heard this week, one person of people who visited this website were actually able to enroll. Gail, you have called this whole thing a complete screw up, you have been an HHS, you've seen what goes on from the inside. Tell us your view on these headlines you're reading.

GAIL WILENSKY, UNITEDHEALTH GROUP BOARD MEMBER: I think what may have been a major contributing factor are two issues. One is that a lot of changes continued from CMS, the agency that is in charge of this for HHS to go to the contractors very late. And it meant that with the client putting change specs to the people putting this together, they didn't really have much of a change -- chance to test before it went online for the real. The reason I say that is some of the large vendors who are supporting the federalist exchanged are the same vendors you are providing support to the state exchanges that are working well.

So, it makes you think there is something about what is going on in those federal exchanges, and the instructions they were getting from the government about how they do it. I read a statistic today that was just amazing to me. This is from a Kaiser News reporter, normally a source, friendly to the administration.

WILLIS: That's right.

WILENSKY: It took him 17 days and 63 attempts in order to enroll. Clearly it's got to fix that, or people are going to go beyond frustration.

WILLIS: Wow, John, I just want to get you and what Gail saying here about what happened with the exchanges, the same company, that some of the same vendors used on the status changes as the federal exchange, that's just she just said. She says, there's something about the way the Fed did this, that screwed it up. What do you say? What do think? You're an expert on this.

ENGATES: Yes. So, this is a massive integration project that crossed a number of departments probably spread out in many states and many federal agencies. And that is a big job, that's a big task. And you have to have expertise in doing that. And obviously, these government contractors do this kind of work, but maybe they did not have it experience that the scale, maybe they didn't have the time to do the legwork that they needed to do to pull together the agencies that are involved. I mean, if you imagine what is going on here, the system is looking up data in a variety of services and data bases all over the counter basically.

WILLIS: Well, that's true. It's bringing together a lot. But they had two in a half years to do it, Paul. And now we are hearing this company CGI, this is behind all of this, this is a Canadian company. It's not even an American company which I think is really funny. There are big time government contractor. The government has been better going with the same guys to develop Google or Amazon or Twitter or Facebook.

HOWARD: Right. So, the government procurement rules actually favor people have done business with the government before, have large lobby arms in Congress. Obviously, if you went with somebody like Google or Adele, you would be better off at this point. CMS also made a critical decision that it was going to be the quarterback for all the private contractors instead of contracting that decision now to somebody who was experience that kind of integration. CMS is not known of its IT healthcare expertise, so that was probably also a critical problem.

WILLIS: Well, there is a lot going on here Gail. You were involved with the Medicare prescription drug program, the roll out of that. And I remember it was originally criticized for being too complicated. That was the media's problem with it. Did it go better than ObamaCare is?

WILENSKY: It certainly did not have these kinds of problems. Every new program has some start up problems. Everyone knew October 1st was going to be a bit rocky and bumpy, as January 1st will be for sure. I do not think anyone anticipated that kind of problems that we're seeing to multiple attempts, people who go part way through, get an error message and get thrown off. This is beyond any expectations that I have heard about. The administration has until the middle of November to get all of these problems reasonably fixed or there's going to be great difficulty in having an effective January 1st.

WILLIS: You know, they're setting up a situation where people are going to break the law because they don't have a way of getting signed on legally. I think that's one of the major stories is not being reported right now, Paul. What do you say to this inability to get this thing together and now we're starting to hear some insurers might actually start their own private exchange because they cannot get anything done with the Obamacare network.

HOWARD: Right. It is a real problem for the insurers, if the only people who get through this process and get enrolled are desperate and sick. That creates a bad health risk for insurers --

TSOMBANAKIS: How about the department passing the buck? Of course they did something wrong. Two people left the prison. How can you sit there and say you didn't do something wrong? Where are these people? How did you not know in this? I mean, please. It's time for government to get with it, get responsible. You let these people out, there's something going on in your prison, fix it. Don't sit there and go, oh, I don't know anything. Well who would then?

WILLIS: But who gets that ball rolling, Regina? I mean how does - what needs to happen next?

TSOMBANAKIS: From the top. From whoever's the warden, whoever's in charge of that prison.

WILLIS: How about the governor?

TSOMBANAKIS: The Department of Corrections.

WILLIS: How about the governor?

TSOMBANAKIS: Yeah, how about the governor? Exactly. Somebody's got to get involved. We're risking people's lives. They've killed before, they probably may kill again, and these victims don't deserve this. And we don't deserve this.

WILLIS: No, I certainly agree.

TSOMBANAKIS: What's the point, you know? If they can check in and out of the hotel?

WILLIS: Well put. Regina Tsombanakis, thank you for coming on. I think I said it right that time. I appreciate your time.

TSOMBANAKIS: Good.

WILLIS: Good job.

TSOMBANAKIS: Thank you.

WILLIS: Thank you. Well, still to come, Fox News meteorologist Janice Dean is here, but she's not telling us the weekend forecast. So, look at her new book. There she is right there. After the break. Freddy the Frogcaster. Well done.

WILLIS: What does the frog have to do with forecasting? More than you might think what Freddy the Frog wants your kids to learn. Coming up.

WILLIS: All right, some kids say they want to be a police officer or a firefighter when they grow up, you know, you don't usually say meteorologist when you're a little kid, but one author's hoping to change all that. Fox News senior meteorologist Janice Dean is here to talk about her new children's book called "Freddy the Froggcaster." I love to say that, and why she feels it's so important kids learn about the weather from an early age. You've got to tell us about this book, it's so adorable.

JANICE DEAN, FOX NEWS SENIOR METEOROLOGIST: Thank you.

WILLIS: I've been able to page through it and look at it, it seems like a great read for kids.

DEAN: Did you learn something from it?

WILLIS: I learned something every single minute. Yes.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: I learned about cold fronts ...

DEAN: Yes.

WILLIS: Of thunderstorm clouds.

DEAN: Yep, I think it's important because I wanted to not only give kids an introduction to weather, but also help parents discuss why things happen in the atmosphere. I think sometimes as parents if I wasn't a meteorologist, I don't know if I would know what a cold front or a warm front or a low pressure/high pressure is, and I think I explain that well enough so that kids and parents can get involved in what's happening outside, and I think that's really important. I think kids at a young age have an appreciation for weather.

WILLIS: Oh, sure. And it's the only thing anybody ever talks about, so if you want your children to be part of the conversation ...

DEAN: Right.

WILLIS: They need to understand the weather.

DEAN: Absolutely. And like you mentioned, it opens up our dialogue with each other. I ride the elevator every day here at Fox, it's a nice day out here, Janice Dean, congratulations.

(LAUGHTER)

DEAN: Or is it going to rain on my parade tomorrow?

(LAUGHTER)

DEAN: So, you know, it brings us together as a community. I think as well if we see a bad storm go through our neighborhood, it also brings us together to help one another. Weather is always going to be a big part of our lives, and I think if we can get kids at an early age to start discovering it more, in the long term it's going to be good for everyone, and it might inspire a new generation of meteorologists.

WILLIS: Well, that's what I think is so interesting. Because one of the things you're saying tomorrow, I understand, in an op-ed editorial to be published is that it's all about math and science.

DEAN: Sure.

WILLIS: And this is a way to get kids interested in that. Tell us how numbers contribute to weather forecasting.

DEAN: Well, it's all about computer models. What we input into the computer models to tell us what the forecast is going to bring, numbers, temperatures, drop in pressure, barometer. Numbers are important when it comes to forecasting, and there's a lot of math, and there's is a lot of science. And we know as we get kids into schools these days if they're going to compete on the world stage, they have to know math, science, technology and engineering. So those two, math and science, that's what meteorology is all about. So if we can get them interested at a young age and think it's fun, maybe they will in turn think that math and science is fun when they go ...

WILLIS: Become an engineer, a meteorologist ...

DEAN: Absolutely.

WILLIS: Who knows? You know, the job openings, this is numbers from 2016, 16 percent of bachelor degrees will specialize in STEM, but the number of jobs that are open, one million. So we're not producing enough kids to actually do these jobs. Anything we can do to inspire them is a positive, right?

DEAN: Absolutely. Yeah, of course. And like I mentioned, when you have an appreciation for weather and you want to learn about it, you're going to learn about it in school, but it is a lot of math, it's a lot of science. I took something like -- that's called thermodynamics. It sounds scary, but it's fun when you can get all the numbers together. And they say this a lot, but weather is not an exact science. It won't be. We can't really predict that perfect forecast yet. But we'll certainly get them encouraged to really love those summits.

WILLIS: One final question, why a frog? How'd you come up with a frog?

DEAN: Well, the groundhog was taken.

(LAUGHTER)

DEAN: Right? And when I thought about it, I've always had a love of frogs. And, you know, Gerri, the interesting thing that I just learned about recently that, you know, gave me inspiration that Freddy was the right choice was that frogs, apparently, when a storm is coming they croak louder. How perfect is that?

WILLIS: They know. They know.

DEAN: Plus, I can also say things like frogcaster, the Frogs News Network, you know, it's cute names like Sally Croaker and Polly Woggins. I had a lot of fun. It's a lot of great names, it's the illustration, Russ Cox did all the illustrations, beautiful job, and at the back of the book there's some educational purpose too. There's a definition, a glossary of all the terms that I use on television.

WILLIS: Every single day.

DEAN: Yeah.

WILLIS: I have to tell you, it's a great book. Great reading.

DEAN: Thank you.

WILLIS: It's about at my level, now I think.

(LAUGHTER)

WILLIS: Thanks for Janice, thanks for coming on.

DEAN: Anytime.

WILLIS: great job. Appreciate it. Well, if you can't get your hands on the Freddy the Frogcaster costume, and you're still looking for some Halloween ideas, tonight's top five might help. The most popular costumes of 2013, well, so far, number five is for those who want to go trick or twerking, Miley Cyrus. He MTV performance is leading to Teddy-bear inspired teddies. Mom and dad shouldn't see that. Number four, break out the camouflage so you can look like the cast of Duck Dynasty. Think beards and bandannas, you know, red neck chic. Number three is a fox. This is from a viral video, in the same (inaudible) as Gangnam style, it's an electronic dance song by a Norwegian artist. Number two, characters from "Breaking Bad." You can look like Walter White or Jesse Pinkman with a yellow hazmat suit that you can buy online for about 45 bucks apiece. And the number one most popular Halloween costume of 2013, the minions from "Despicable Me." I love that. You can dress up your child as a small, yellow, cylindrical creatures for about 35 bucks. Costumes for mom and dad, a little more expensive. Other looks on the list, characters from the "Game of Thrones" or the classic, Batman. We'll be right back.

WILLIS: The problems with Obamacare just don't stop. As insurers are now reporting the system is generating massive amounts of flawed data. Do you think these glitches will be enough to force the president to delay the individual mandate? Here is what some of you are posting on my Facebook page. Sandy says this, "I think the backlash will be so bad they will cancel it and transfer those folks in need to Medicaid. Interesting. And Maxine writes this, "No, because it would mean failure." That is possible, too. We also asked this question on Geriwillis.com. 20 percent of you said yes, 80 percent said no. "The president will not delay the mandate." And finally, you know, I cannot get over how bad Obamacare is. Look, I did not expect it to be successful, but I did not expect it a disaster either, and it has become just one more thing you have to figure out. The responsibility on your shoulders because the government sure is not helping you.

Look, I am getting tons of tweets, Facebook post, e-mails, all great questions and all deserving answers. So, we are stepping in again with another call-in show on Monday. Join us. I have a panel of experts, people who are not Obama-paid consultants to tell you the real deal on Obamacare. Look, we get it. You are squeezed. It is you against Obamacare, you against the IRS. You against the companies that see your wallet as their bottom line. So, we'll be there again. I hope you will join us Monday at 6:00 P.M. That is it for tonight's "WILLIS REPORT." Thanks for joining us. We will see you here Monday.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:51KG-8XW1-JCB3-41SX-00000-00Obama falls short on tech issues2010-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:14:38ZLexisNexisHIGH-TECHObama falls short on tech issuesBy MIKE ZAPLER MediaNews

WASHINGTON He was the embodiment of the modern, high-tech president when he took office: the first to fully harness the Internet to build a political movement, the first commander in chief to carry a BlackBerry, the first to promise to instill Silicon Valley sensibilities in the federal bureaucracy.

However, halfway through President Barack Obama's first term, he has yet to deliver on much of his sweeping tech agenda, tempering the high expectations many in the industry had when he took office.

A research and development tax credit that Obama pledged to make permanent lapsed at the end of last year and remains dormant. Legislation to invest in basic research and math and science education is bottled up in Congress. And while the federal stimulus bill directed billions of dollars to clean energy, health IT and broadband deployment money long sought by the tech sector Obama has disappointed the industry in critical areas such as tax policy and trade.

It's not that the president has abandoned his positions on key issues or doesn't appreciate technology and innovation, industry representatives say. On issues such as clean tech and broadband, he's done more in two years, some of them argue, than his predecessor, George W. Bush, did in two terms.

But there is still a palpable sense of disappointment. The recurring complaint is that the administration so far hasn't prioritized tech issues or devoted the time or energy to surmount resistance in Congress. And that resistance is certain to grow stronger after the Republican takeover of the House of Representatives, especially to any tech proposals that require more federal dollars.

"It is such a big improvement, it's awkward to say they're not doing enough," said Ed Black, president and CEO of the Computer & Communications Industry Association. "But although they have articulated some wise, important goals when it comes to tech issues, implementation and achievement are sorely lacking."

Obama's tech platform as a candidate included a laundry list of items, but fundamentally he saw the federal government's role as part investor, part regulator. Strategic spending on clean energy, broadband deployment and research and development, he said, would help the U.S. compete globally and potentially yield new cutting-edge industries. On the regulation front, Obama proposed Net neutrality, the idea favored by many Silicon Valley innovators that the owners of Internet networks should not be allowed to prioritize traffic of their choosing.

Obama's proposals on taxes and trade two other areas of major importance to Silicon Valley were seen as somewhat less friendly to big high-tech companies. He proposed preventing multinational companies from deferring taxes on overseas profits, and he supported expanding free trade agreements only when tougher labor and environmental standards were included.

White House officials say Obama has made good headway on his proposals to make the federal government more open and transparent through the Web, and to accommodate the explosion of wireless devices with a plan to free up radio spectrum. The president is still committed to double federal spending on basic research during the next decade, one of his main tech-related campaign proposals, they say.

On other issues, such as taxes and Net neutrality, the aides say, it's too early to judge Obama.

"The plane hasn't landed yet," said Aneesh Chopra, the White House's chief technology officer, a position newly created by Obama.

Large investment

Much of the progress Obama has made was through the $814 billion stimulus bill. Though that spending was temporary, it provided the biggest federal investment in alternative energy, high-speed Internet deployment and health IT in decades.

"There is no idea in alternative energy that the recovery act did not touch," said Wade Randlett, a Silicon Valley clean-energy entrepreneur and Obama supporter who predicted that the spending "would pay dividends for decades."

The president also receives kudos for an ambitious plan to extend broadband to all Americans, unveiled by the Federal Communications Commission earlier this year. The commission has begun to take steps on some of the recommendations, such as freeing up airwaves known as "white spaces" to accommodate the proliferation of wireless devices.

But little has happened in other areas. An early push for Net neutrality rules by Obama's FCC chairman, Julius Genachowski, has sputtered since a court decision challenged the commission's authority over broadband. Obama's recent trip to Asia ended without a much-anticipated trade agreement with South Korea. Trade pacts with Colombia and Panama have also stalled.

Tax antagonism

On taxes, Obama antagonized the business community, including big high-tech firms, with a proposal to increase taxes on overseas profits. Though the initiative went nowhere, Obama hasn't said the idea is off the table.

"The administration has been very helpful on innovation funding, rhetorically helpful but ineffective on opening markets and fundamentally unhelpful on international tax policy," said Bruce Mehlman, a Republican lobbyist and former Commerce Department assistant secretary for technology policy.

R&D tax credit expires

Others say Obama's rhetoric has outpaced his accomplishments in some areas. The president has gone out of his way to highlight the importance of science and math education, hosting science fairs at the White House and recruiting companies to advocate for the cause.

But legislation to boost the country's competitiveness with funding for basic research during the campaign, Obama proposed doubling the National Science Foundation's budget and for science and technology education remains bogged down in the Senate. And an R&D tax credit widely used by high-tech firms expired at the end of last year, despite Obama's call to expand the credit and make it permanent.

With mounting concerns about federal debt and a new class of Republican lawmakers bent on curbing government spending, getting either item through Congress could become more challenging because of their multibillion-dollar price tags.

The R&D credit "has never lapsed for that long before, and it's just outrageous," said Robert Atkinson, president of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a technology think tank. "The administration could have done a lot more to say this is a high priority, it has to happen."

Philip Weiser, a senior White House adviser on technology and science issues, said the president will continue to press for spending on basic research and science and math education.

"You're going to see this two-pronged message," he said. "We have to be fiscally responsible but we also have to lay the groundwork for future prosperity."

Obama's tech scorecard Taxes ·Promised: Tax overseas corporate profits, which are now deferred as long as the money is kept abroad. ·Progress: Stalled, to the relief of big tech firms. Research and development ·Promised: Make R&D tax credit permanent, or even more generous. ·Progress: Credit expired in 2009. Open government ·Promised: Hire a chief technology officer, make government data more accessible. ·Progress: CTO hired, federal agencies ordered to create open-government plans. Tech/research investment ·Promised: Double National Science Foundation budget, devote $150 billion over 10 years to clean tech. ·Progress: Stimulus had tens of billions of dollars for clean tech and electronic health records, but funding for research, science and math education tied up in Congress. Broadband ·Promised: Enact Net neutrality, free up spectrum for wireless devices, close the broadband digital divide. ·Progress: Net neutrality stymied, ambitious broadband plan unveiled, some progress.

President Barack Obama checks out a robot that can play soccer, invented by students from Wissahickon High School in Ambler, Pa., as he tours the students' science fair projects exhibits on Oct. 18 in the State Dining Room of the White House.
